You'd think that since she's supposed to be even more advanced than the T-1000 SkyNet would have been able to make her less "robotic" in her movements and speech. Hell, the way they look at you with glazed, steely eyes you wouldn't need dogs to detect them.All in all the movie proved to be a big disappointment for me.

Review title: Why I think Terminator 3 doesn't deliver! - Spoilers
Review_body: I am a HUGE Terminator fan. I have seen both the first two movies inside out and backwards. Here is why I do not believe that Terminator three belongs on the same level as the first two. Forgive me if I leave out any information in my arguments and should anyone feel the desire to argue my points, then by all means you're more than welcome. The first thing that got me about the third movie was the emotion both the terminators showed. The terminator was set up as a relentless killing machine that doesn't show pity, remorse or fear, simply systematic destruction. Ironically, during the scene when the terminator is reprogrammed by the T-X he explains to John (rather emphatically) that he is a machine. That line would have been much more effective had it been delivered with the cold, hard apathy we saw in the first two terminators. Another emotional moment for the terminator was the T-X this time. *(This shouldn't be a spoiler but use discretion anyway) Just before the T-X is defeated she shows fear! If the terminator can't cry in the second movie after all he's been through, I find it very hard to believe that this T-X can be afraid.*(Potential Spoilers in the following paragraph) That whole thing with the power cell really annoyed me. In the first terminator, he is crushed under a hydraulic press. He didn't blow up! In the third, they suddenly make it that if he suffers a massive blow to the chest he is in danger of exploding. Further more, I understand that this next comment could be taken as being a little nit-picky, but I believe it has to be said. At the end of the second movie the terminator specifically states that he cannot self-terminate, yet at the end of the third movie he decidedly drops the door on himself and the T-X, knowing it would destroy them both.OK, John Conner is a wimp in this movie. By the end of the second movie he is supposed to be half ready for the war, and before Sarah died, she was supposed to have taught him to be a "Great military leader". How much of this showed in the third now that Judgment day was right around the corner? Also, Cyberdyne Systems was destroyed in the second movie, along with all traces of the terminator. This should have prevented the war. OK, so it never, it only postponed it. *(Spoiler alert) Skynet turns out to be a virus, that becomes self aware, and will construct the terminator (Cyberdyne Systems model 101) based on what? Huh? Military records? How did they get them if Cyberdyne systems was destroyed? Even if Skynet developed this model of the terminator through some kind of cybernetic evolution, he still wouldn't have been developed in the short amount of time they gave in the movie.

Review title: The trailers made this movie look bad!
Review_body: I was a little nervous going into this movie because of the trailers, but my skepticism was for nothing.  The movie is great!  TONS of action, good story (I think they resolve this issues of judgment day and skynet very well). I'm VERY into the first two movies and I believe this one is a fantastic sequel and you shouldn't be disappointed.

sequel season 2003 continues, this time for a movie that was made 10 years ago. the plot remains the same: two 'terminator'-class machines are sent back from the future to the present time. one of them is sent to assassinate, and the other to protect. the targetted individuals again are unaware or do not accept their future importance, and the humor is on the same lines, including a reference to the famous Hasta La Vista from Terminator 2. As expected, the main attractions in this movie are the computer generated effects and the beautiful actresses (this time around the machine-sent terminator takes the form of the sexy Kristanna Loken). Nothing is surprising in this film, it takes the exact same things that made the first 2 movies a hit and jumbles them all back together into this bland product. Special effects are okay, nothing too exciting or innovative, and the plot is just dumb. If you hated the rest of the sequels this season (Matrix 2, Charlie's Angels 2, etc) you'll hate this one as well. don't waste your time/money - don't encourage the studios to make more crap.
Good action, moving ending. Otherwise a bit too much of a retread of T2. And Claire Danes is a better actress than to spend most of the movie screamingArnold is ok. Nothing special

Here are the problems with T3: The terminatrix has absolutely no presence on the screen. Her abilities are so vast that it becomes boring after a few minutes. Her arm reminded me of Inspector gadget. Arnies script is so bad that even his one liners don't come off. Most of his dialouge had me raising my eyes to heaven and wishing Mr Cameron was still in charge. John Connor is a complete loser. The actor portaying him is really bad. Avoid this film at all costs

If you read some reviews that said this movie sucks,don't listen to them. I seriously liked this move alot!!!Great special effects nice acting and cool fighting scenes!This movie on a scale of 1 to 10,I gave it a ten!I really recommend this move!It really is great to have Arnold back!Though,the only flaw of this move is that it is not as brutal as the first 2 terminator movies!But,theres a seen where T-X punches threw a cop!And few other brutal scenes.This indeed is one of the best movies of summer!Rated R for Strong sci-fi action and violence,and for Language and Brief nudity.

Review title: Not sure why they told us this story
Review_body: I came out of this movie with mixed emotions. The special effects were good, the chases were tense and the backstory of this new Terminator's relationship with John Connor was clever. Still, there was a fatalism throughout the movie that reduced the impact of the ending. The movie essentially says to us, "This is the way things will turn out...things are turning out as I predicted...I was right, this was the way turned out." Not only does this ruin suspense, but it also means that whenever someone dies in the picture, instead of pitying the dead, we shrug and move on. It alienates us from the movie and its characters when we want to feel close, and by the end my reaction to the story paralleled that of the kid in The Princess Bride who screams, "Jeez, grampa, why did you want to tell me this story!"

Review title: Surprisingly good! But in this movie John Connor is an impotent, indecisive, half-wit!
Review_body: I was prepared for the worst ... but hey it was pretty good! I'd give this movie about 7/10 ... it could have been 8/10 or better ... were it not for the badly scripted role of the John Connor character. In this movie John Conner is an impotent, indecisive, half-wit!After the T2 you'd think this guy would be more clued in! Yet in here he seems pretty confused by the whole scenario. He even goes and has a little hissy fit in the mausoleum "why me? why me?" ... idiot your mom's been telling you this your whole life ... now's not the time to act like a pathetic twit! This is the guy who's going to lead the human race? He was supposed to be trained to be a soldier and a leader ... yet he's reduced to the role of a spectator in most of the action scenes! In some of the most climactic scenes Connor is portrayed to have no sense of urgency! There are several scenes where, in the face of danger, he hesitates and stares dumbly at the approaching menace before running away rather impotently. There's even a scene where he and his 'future wife' are frozen in shock as the TX approaches ... and all the while a gun is lying on the ground in front of them. Guess who picks up the gun? The girl! By the end of this movie I want John Conner to die! I don't care if the whole human race will die with him.If this is the best leader we can come up with its about time we're all replaced by machines.

Review title: Very good movie which almost lives up to its predecessors
Review_body: Despite the views of some critics, I found this movie to be a solid piece of entertainment. Following on the heels of the 1984 sci-fi action classic "The Terminator" and its sequel "Terminator 2: Judgment Day", the plot once again centres around an attempt by machines from the future to eliminate John Connor, the man destined to become the saviour of humankind.Still afraid for his life, John now lives "off the grid" with no phone or known address to avoid being traced. One can understand his reasons, since a shapeshifting liquid metal cyborg (in the guise of T2's Robert Patrick) tried to kill him when he was still a child. Despite that the foretold nuclear war on August 29, 1997 (see the earlier flicks) failed to materialise, John still suspects all has not been set right. His fears are justified when another cyborg assassin, the T-X who assumes the form of a 5' 11'' blonde female, is sent back to eliminate his unsuspecting lieutenants (initially at least) on the eve of the postponed -- not averted -- nuclear war in the hope of changing the outcome of the future war between humans and sentient machines bent on their destruction. Once again, the resistance sends back another terminator (Arnold Schwarzenegger, who else?) to protect John from the more advanced model. Why not send back a T-1000 or T-X instead? Well, I suppose capturing a liquid man (or woman) alive would be somewhat difficult, so it kinda makes sense.There are many absentees from the earlier movies, notably Linda Hamilton (John's mother Sarah in T1 and T2), Edward Furlong (John in T2) and not least the writer/director John Cameron. This time, the director is Johnathan Mostow, whose previous credits include Breakdown and U-571. However, I feel the director brought a new feel to the movie and all worked out quite well.Newcomers Nick Stahl and Claire Danes (who plays Katherine Brewster, one of John's future lieutenants) aquit themselves quite well and have good on-screen chemistry. Kristanna Loken (the supermodel turned actress who plays the T-X) is very convincing and has the same icy look that Robert Patrick had in T2. Arnold is getting a bit old for this type of movie now, but he still has the screen presence needed to liven things up.The movie is generally more light hearted than its two predecessors, though there is the odd dark scene mixed in. There are plenty of gags, some of which are effective and some which don't quite work. The T-X's abilities are interesting. Without giving too much away, she is somewhat a hybrid of the T-101 and T-1000, a metal endoskelton with advanced weapons surrounding by liquid metal, able to assume the forms of other people and control other machines (which leads to some interesting situations).T3 is entertaining throughout. Most of the movie is spent with the T-X chasing the heroes (and heroine), kind of similar to T1, but without the prolonged story-driven sections in the middle of T2. There are some very good action sequences, notably a chase seen early on, although I feel they could have made the movie a little longer (perhaps just over two hours) with a more climatic fight between the T-101 and T-X. Despite a good earlier fight scene, she is despatched a little too easily at the end, considering she is supposed to be an anti-terminator terminatrix (according to the T-101 anyway). The fight between the T-101 and T-1000 in the steel mill at the end of T2 was superior, as was the battle between Sarah and the T-101 in the Cyberdyne factory in the original. Also, there are sections where they don't really use the T-X as well as they could have. I think some of the gory sections (which would have made her a more scary character and on a par with Robert Patrick) were cut. For instance, she threatens a cop but we don't actually see him die. There's also a scene where she saws somebody up but we only see the splattering blood.All in all, an entertaining summer blockbuster (not quite as good as X2 but better than the Matrix Reloaded) and a worthy follow up, though not as groundbreaking as the previous two films.Eccentric Brit rates it 8/10 (T1 and T2 both 9/10)

Review title: Exactly what I expected - I'd even see it again.
Review_body: This movie was exactly what I expected it to be.  It wasn't as good as Terminator 2, but it was still a very entertaining action movie, with a few neat ideas thrown in to boot.  The acting was decent(Claire Danes I especially liked, and Arnold is great as usual),even if the movie was heavily weighted towards action scenes, and the new female terminator really rocks.My favorite part of this movie was the ending... it ties everything together, and leaves you wondering.  I don't want to spoil it, but I thought it was an excellent twist, that left me thinking about it days later.

I went into this movie with a very low expectation.  After so many bad movies this summer I was sure they were going to ruin Terminator as well. That however did not occur.  The filmmakers obviously knew that they were not up to the task of coming up with a coherent story line so they just decided to have two hours of non-stop violence.  Add to the mix some outstanding one-liners and very twisted time humor and you end up with a movie that was refreshingly good.  If you are looking for a film that will get you emotionally involved as you watch the characters struggle with themselves to grow...this is the wrong film.  If on the other hand you just really want to see a bunch of stuff get blown up then this movie is right for you.  8/10

Not as good as t1 or t2 but still overpassed my expectations, thinking that this is the 3rd movie in the series and James cameron wasnt directing it i was expecting a blow out, but i got the opposite, i didnt get what i got from the prior films ( got u thinkin bout how the world will end) but i got a great action film and lots of comic relief. The ending was great but although pretty cheesy, but what can u expect from an Arnold movie? Great summer movie with amazing special effects( in my opinion better then the matrix reloaded), go see it, 8 or 9 out of 10.

I can't believe it. After five years of reading through rumours and gossip, it has finally been unleashed. After a year of antcipating this movie and watching the previews over and over again "it is time". Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is here, and holy crap did come in style.This movie blows all of the other summer movies away.Before I go on, I must say this; MINOR SPOILERS (nothing drastic) will be given away.The movie opens with John Connor now in his 20's. He's living off the radar, and moves around a lot. He sort of a has been now. Since they stopped Judgment Day from happening ten years previous, he has nothing to live for really. However, he's still paranoid and never forgets what his mom taught him. But now another, highly advanced terminator (Kristana Loken) has been sent back to, well, terminate him. The T-X, as it's called, goes around and kills all of John's future Lieutenants. The T-X also goes after a girl named Kate Brewster (Claire Daines) who we find out has a very important role in the future war. The Human Resistance was able to send back another Terminator (Schwarzenegger) to protect Connor and Brewster. But which one will reach him first?Now, I'll get to the good stuff in awhile but first I want to mention the casting. The casting of Nick Stahl as Connor was great. I first saw Stahl in the Mel Gibson directed movie The Man With-out A Face. Then Stahl was just a kid, but he did a great job in the role he played. Stahl replaces Edward Furlong in the role of Connor and he does a great job at it. His performance is brilliant and the way he captures the character of a guy who knows that the world could be destroyed at anytime is excellent.The casting of Claire Daines as Kate Brewster was a smart move as well. I can't actually think of any other actress who would fit in this role. As much as I like Natalie Portman, I don't think she would have been believable in this role, and it would have just been her doing her Star Wars bit again. Daines and Stahl have some great chemistry on screen together and that really helps the movie. That's one thing that can always hurt a movie if people are supposed to like each other. Bad chemistry is noticeable, and it distracts from the picture.Now onto the choice role of the T-X, Kristana Loken. While she doesn't play the character as menacing as Robert Patrick's T-1000 character in T2, she does do a good job, at being the, sort of, innocent cute girl. She actually surprised me and did a good job. She's not a scary character, which is a shame, but she's a tough one. I wasn't to keen on the idea of a female terminator, I though it would be handled wrong, but I was wrong. I suppose that's what I get for under-estimating Jonathan Mostow, who did good job with this movie.Sure T3 isn't as good as the first two. I didn't expect it to be, and it doesn't bother me. First of all, it's a different director and writers. The James Cameron Terminator movies are far superior to this one, but this one is still a worthy sequel.Mostow, who directed the great Kurt Russell thriller 'Breakdown' and the tense submarine thriller 'U-571', handles this movie really well. He pays homage to the original Terminator movies as well as adding his own spin on it.This one isn't as 'dark' as the other ones were, but it still works. I have said for awhile now, that this movie will either crush Mostow's career, or give him the respect he deserves. And it looks like I'm right.
Mostow has an eye for action, and a well placed eye that is. Most of the action in this movie is way better than most of the other action in any of the previous summer action movies.And another good thing is it never lets up. The action just keeps coming. What a thrill ride. The massive car chase near the beginning was brilliant. I said the Matrix: Reloaded car chase was good, but this one is far better, mainly because it uses REAL cars and real stunts. It doesn't rely on CGI to make explosions and cars crash.The first car chase, or rather truck chase, is fun and thrilling. It involves a crane truck and Arnie chasing the T-X on a police motorcycle. It's too much to talk about it, but it's great. What I also liked about this chase was something very subtle. The chase started a night, but it ended during the day. I loved the fact that Mostow decided to have the sun come up during the chase. I don't know why. Probably because most car chases either happen during the day or night, never in between. It was a nice touch. Lame I know, but I liked it.The rest of the action is skillfully done and it was some neat stuff to see. A fight between the Terminator and the T-X had me worried for a minute that Woman's Rights Activists might sue the studio because of the beating Arnie gives the female T-X. But then she fought back, so I guess it evens the score.Also, I must mention Stan Winston. He worked on the previous two Terminators and even won an Academy Award for make-up and special effects on T2. He returns here, and does a stellar job. I love seeing the battle damage on the Terminator, with the Terminator skeleton popping out and flesh still hanging on. It's really neat make-up and job well done. I think another Academy Award might in sights for Winston.Now there was a lot of humour in this one. I laughed at a lot of it, and it was nice to kind of see Arnie play around and make fun of himself on screen. Like just after he gets his outfit and what he does. It was stupid, but I will admit, I laughed. It was harmless, but it could have done with-out it.Now, there were some things that I didn't like about T3. Yes, I know, hard to believe, eh? I didn't like some of the dialogue. It was weak at times, but all the goodness about this movie makes up for all the bad.I also didn't like the fact the classic Terminator theme was absent through out the whole movie. Now Marco Beltrami did a god job composing the movie. The soundtrack was great, it's just, I missed that Terminator theme. It's such an awsome theme, how could he not use it? Sure it appears in the end credits, but still?The story moves along at break neck pace and keeps rolling and rolling. The movie does slow down from time to time to explain things and further the story as well. I don't want to say anything about the story in general, but what I will say is that it's pretty good.In Roger Ebert's review he said `The ending must remain for you to discover, but I will say it seems perfunctory'. I disagree. I liked the ending. As did Ebert's reviewing buddy Richard Roeper. It does leave questions out there, but it also seems to say that, no matter how much we try, we are always doomed. You can't stop something from happening that's supposed to happen, you can only postpone it, and wait until it arrives to do what your fate has chosen for you to do.The ending was good. I liked it. I don't care what anyone says about it, it was good.So, now my closing comments, Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is a summer action movie that delivers. It doesn't have a complicated storyline that makes you stop paying attention and makes you just want to leave the theatre so bad (Matrix Reloaded). It doesn't rely heavily on CGI like the Matrix did, and when it has CGI, its damn good. It's not as noticeable or poorly done like the Matrix and Hulk were. It also has non-stop great action.It's a great movie and I know I've said this before, but I recommend seeing this. Go buy a ticket, buy some popcorn sit down and enjoy the lame, but fun, humour, the action and spectacular visuals.I have to say it, but Arnold is back everyone, and he's back in full force. Terminator 3 is here, and now its time for King Conan.

This movie is awesome.  Terminator is not about man against machine, it is not about the end of the world, it IS about one liners spoken in an austrian accent by a man who could at one point bench two of you put together.  I laughed so hard I almost got kicked out of the theatre.  By the way, cameron is the wrong guy for terminator.  he is too serious and deep.The new director finally realized terminator's potential as a comedy, and exploited arnold's arnoldness to create the most lighthearted and funny terminator yet.  It is too bad that all three weren't like this.  Anyone who complains about his movie is a loser who can't lighten up and just have a good time.  This is the best arnold flick since   "Last Action Hero".

Review title: Doesn't compare to the first 2, but still fun
Review_body: Comparing this to the originals is a no win situation. It's inferior to both, but still a solid entry. It may irk some fans with the direction it goes, but overall...if you like action and some great Terminator lines then I think you'll enjoy it. I feared this movie would be a total piece of garbage, so my expectations weren't high. Because I wasn't anticipating a "bar raising" entry into the series I think it allowed me to enjoy it for what it was. It's Terminator Light...less thought goes into it and the pacing just screams forward. The frantic pace actually helps distract you from the problems with the script/plot. It's all about the action and nostalgic humor. You will have fun when you see this, but don't expect anything resembling the masterpiece of T2 that Cameron crafted. Oh, and Kristanna Loken is easily the hottest robot that has ever graced film...and she is entirely believable in her role.
Love this episode,this rating 6,3 is very strange...

Review title: Overall entertaining, but far from the quality of T2
Review_body: I thought the movie kept its traditional sci fi action appeal.  However the story was a little weak, there could have been more story lines in between the action.  Also the action was tamed down to a PG level,  What happend to the good old days back in the 80s with the maxium blood gore and vilolence R-Rated all the way.    I give this film a 7/10

Review title: I wanted to cry tears of pain
Review_body: I grew up loving Terminator. Especially the second movie. And this movie completely sucks in almost every way.I keep trying to find something redeeming about it. I'm trying to force myself with mental back-flips into somehow making this movie not the worst film I had ever seen. The only thing good this film did was judgment day. But, that would have served better as a two or three minute prologue to T4 and T4 could have been T3 and things would be much better.(Judgment day was pro-longed but not stopped, now to the movie.) The movie tries to be funny, and falls on its face by taking treasured scenes and turning them into half-baked and crappy jokes. It tries to change storyline, in all the wrong ways. Everything feels forced. You almost wish that Arnold will stop talking because everything he says just destroys any sense the previous two movies every made. (Not that they were perfect; but T3 took 'creative liberties' to an obscene level where they were pulling crap out of their butt left and right and not even checking if it had any dramatic reason to be there, make fans happy, or even make any sense.) The took my child-hood hero that was emotionally strong and turned him into a whiny a** drug addict. I grew up watching T2 and playing with T2 toys sense I was about five. As I got older, I saw John as a role model of emotional maturity; someone with strong leadership skills that I would someday want to be.Now he's a whiny little b**ch for some reason that has never really been explained. He never was before. Had no reason for becoming. It's not like he was unstable and this was in the cards. Of all the characters in T2, T1 even, he was the most emotionally mature and most level headed; even talking his mom down from killing a man.Now? Now he'd go pop some dog neutering pills and be out for hours. Wow, did the writer have nothing better to do than defecate on my childhood? The Terminator series has always been about making your own fate, your own future. That's how things really work. That is a large part of Spirituality. The movie itself even shows that the future was changed. Skynet was set back, that itself is a change. So why does the film go on and on trying to refute how things really Spiritually work, how they worked in T1, how they worked in T2, and how they work even in this film. It just seems that John was just such a whiny runt that he gave up on saving the future.I almost wanted the Arnold Terminator to shoot John dead in the movie so he would just stop whining so damn much. Boo hoo, the future, boo hoo, his life sucks, boo hoo. How did John go from emotionally stable leader to emo drug addict thumb sucker? This film felt like those making it took personal pleasure in taking everything the first two films had ever done well, and every way positive they touched my life, and just shredded it.Part 4 does a great job it trying to put a coherent story back together after 3. I like Part 4, actually. At least it understood what it was supposed to be. But it had two classics to stand up to and a lot of baggage from 3 to deal with. So, I think Part 4 did the best it could considering and I like Part 4 a lot.As for Part 3, it was just sad.

Review title: Wow! Much better than I expected, good film!
Review_body: I went to see T3 with moderate expectations but halfway through the film I found myself really impressed with the third Terminator film.As expected, T3 has lots of action but much of it is done well in conveying the story.  There is an especially intense vehicle chase and it's been a while since I've watch one on film that didn't bore me to some extent. I've read some reviews that complained that T3 didn't show off a lot of special effects and seemed-scaled back.  This is not the case of all.  One of the good things about T3 is that it doesn't bombard you with lots of CGI and other effects.  And some of the effects here are quite impressive.T3 also has quite a bit of humor especially in the first half of the film. I wasn't expecting this as much but it was fun and it did a good job of balancing against action.The ending of the film is perhaps the best asset.  It stays true to the first Terminator film and leaves you thinking about dangers technology going amok and the value of life.T3 is more a enjoyable action, sci-fi film than the Matrix Reloaded and in many ways better than T2.

I didn't know what to expect when I went to see this movie and I ended up seeing it again because I liked it so much. I am a huge fan of the first two and this one was just as good and fun to watch. Especially the kick ass car chase scene (personally my favorite part of the movie). All in all it was a great film.

"What ever you want to see honey," is what I told my husband.  I had no clue that Cameron was not majorly involved in this movie.  I knew that Furlong was not going to be on the screen and hated that.  I whispered to hubby before the movie, you know if they do a T4, I don't care of Arnold is in next one.  That is how low my expectations were for this film.I left the movie going WOW!!!  I loved the action.  Some action came so fast and so furious that this non computerized brain could not process what it had just seen.  Alot of action was hard hitting.One reviewer stated Dane's character was not very credable especially when she locked up John Conner and did not go running for help.   I would like to think that this character had some backbone and was a strong person, knowing that she knew him, felt that there was no need to panic, yet.  And in the long run that is who she needed to be.Other reviews I have read say there is no story line.  I saw that TX (the latest model of terminator) was intent on its mission  (ITS - non gender its not human)  Like a machine with specific tasks TX took the straightest possible route from point A and point B.One person commented on how they did not like that TX said "I like your gun" while other Terminator models made same comments on objects they were about to take.  I assumed that this was the film makers way of telling us how the TX was going remove the cop from its path.As for Furlong not being in the movie, by the end of the movie I felt that the new actor represented John Conner the adult, the scared face warrior of the future.I loved seeing the Dr from T2.  I thought it was a nice sentimental touch. (Maybe Cameron-esque)Lastly,  The T100 unit (Arnold) was not portrayed as compassionate (for those who have not seen T2 on DVD - there is footage that shows changes made to the terminator allowing him to learn gain a bit of humanity)  This was not the same machine from the previous movies and I liked the reinforcement of that fact.While this movie may have disappointed some, I found it completed a circle between the three films and if this is the last of the Terminator movies I think it was well done.And as Dennis Miller use to say... Thats my opinion.. I could be wrong.

I was clueless as what to expect when I went into T3, but when I left, all I could say is wow.  In a world where sequels equal crap, T3 is an exception to the rule.  With amazing special effects, incredible fight sequences, surprisingly good acting, direction, and story, (and of course the hot hot hot Kristina Loken) this is a summer blockbuster to be reckoned with.

Review title: The original crew dropped out, this is what happened
Review_body: Being that there are so many points in Terminator 3:Rise of the Machines which could make you realize its a bad movie, its hard to determine the first one that really makes you give up all hope for the remaining hours. I'll help you because its really quite obvious; When Arnold pulls out shades from his leather jacket, puts them and realizes that (Ha Ha!) there star shaped!! Then he smirks and crunches them. If he had left them on you really wouldn't have noticed because the rest of the movie is spent with the bad-ass T-1000 cracking inside joke one-liners about how "robotic" he is. In an attempt to top T2000 (from T2), they decided that the cool metal skeleton robot could be covered by the really cool liquid metal to form the coolest robot ever! Obviously they realized how stupid that was and just decided to make it a hot chick who can do, literally, anything. You know where this is going because they recycled it from the second movie. John Connors must be saved blah blah blah. The few writing elements which are new to T3 are old to anyone who's seen a movie before.Even though Arnold has way too many lines for a killing machine, he still plays a great robot. Its easy to pick apart actors who play robots but this was always his best role and he does it better than anyone else. When she wasnt the butt of a joke or timing out the perfect punchline, Clair Danes delivers the only other believable performance in T3. I guess she slipped through the cracks because Nick Stahl and Krisstana Loken text book "acted" there way through the entire movie draining life out of the already decaying script. If you could orchestrate the perfect bad movie scene by scene you would inevitabley produce T3. It was exciting to watch. Each scene that went by I grew more and more excited to see how they could possibly make this movie any worse. Amazingly, through bad direction weak acting and horrendous writing, they did it! Too bad the Wayans brothers werent involved, at least then we would have known it was going to be a spoof.

There is no point on this topic, really... I just wanted to express the fact that i laughed my *** out of the "talk to the hand" gag - on both times. Also, those star-ultra-gay glasses that Arnold first takes are making me laugh till now. Damn funny...

People have said no cameron, no hamilton, no furlong, this movie will flop but schwarzenegger has proved the critics wrong. This movie rocked, i liked the script alot and i will not ruin the movie for anyone who hasn't seen it but the action scenes were awesome. The female terminator was good and arnold looks in incredible shape for this movie, he doesn't look like an old man to me. Nick Stahl was pretty good as connor and claire danes was decent but i will give credit to mastow because he made a great movie despite the no cameron backlash

I'm going to admit director Jonathan Mostow had some balls to make this, your making another entry in the Terminator series, two of the greatest films of all time! Many people call this an astonishing summer action flick, but to me a hardcore Terminator fan this is just a big middle finger insult. The plot is it's 20 years later John Connor is moving across the world so that no more Terminators an find him. BUT! They do find him the T-800 (Schwarzenegger of course) and The T-X then it's basically the same plot as Judgment Day. James Cameron tied a knot so hard at the ending of Terminator 2 that they had to cheat the source material in this one Judgment day is not preventable and so the T-800 has to get them to a safe zone. You know for the T-X to be the newest unit it's really no where as advance as the T-1000 in the second one. The T-X might be more flexible and can still morph into people but the T-1000 can do that also he can form knives and stabbing objects to which to me is pretty badass. Nick Stahl is the new John Connor. I don't like him as John Connor at all. For one thing I thought John Connor would be this complete bad ass of a kid when he gets older, but he just seems like some wimp, plus his foul mouth language is gone, his advice to The T-800 well I don't remember him giving anything remember able to him. I mean Edward Furlong created the personality for John Connor and there was deep character development, for me Nick Stahl didn't really give me any personality for the older John Connor, I didn't feel like I knew John Connor at all, unless John was just suppose to grow up awkwardly, sure he seems less annoying then Edward Furlong but he just doesn't fit as the older John Connor, though I will admit I thought he was better than Christen Bale is Salvation. I'm glad Schwarzenegger did The T-800 again; if he did not choose to do it again then I would have never wanted to be made. He still doing what he does best, playing a badass machine, but his character kind of takes a step down because there is no character change. In the second one he went from a machine doing his mission into a father like figure for John. In this one he's just doing the mission. But he is still humorous and still fun to watch which is still good for me, but I was disappointed he didn't say "I'll be back", but with out a doubt he is the best part of the movie. There is also a new character; Claire Danes plays Kate Brewster essentially going to be John's husband in the future. Honestly I just thought she was awful. The T-X killed her husband and morphed into him. When they find each other the T-X morph back into itself, the expression on her face isn't what I expected, it looks like she saw a ghost, plus I thought she was just super annoying and I never felt she was actually scared plus she never really created a personality and the one thing she a John had in common is that they went to the same high school together and the more they spent time together I never felt they could ever get along with each other. I never saw a relationship for them. When I first rated this I gave it a 0% but I felt like I was being too harsh. To me the biggest flaw was the acting. The Claire didn't give her character a personality and Nick did awful as John Connor. In the first one everyone had a personality even Miles did and it made the movie incredibly suspenseful, you want them to stop Judgment day. In here there was no suspense and I honestly didn't care if the made it or not. Also I didn't like how it's basically the same plot as Terminator 2. They made me think that they didn't care about anything except the action in this. Now The Terminator is known to have great and I mean great action sequences make that many great action sequences. In this one for me the very best action sequence is the one where the terminator is hanging from the crane, I thought that was completely bad ass, also the part where the Terminator is carrying John in the coffin I thought that was pretty original. The other action sequences to me were just boring and didn't live up to the hype that I expected. Back then I had a lot of complaints about the action but today I just realize it was just nick-picking (if I said that right). Director Ang Lee was actually offered to direct this but he turned it down to direct the Hulk film, I'm not sure how it would've turned out if he directed this, he probably would have done a better job with the action sequences, well considering what he did to The Hulk maybe, but he is still a better director than Jonathan Mostow. Besides from Schwarzenegger still being a delight to watch and a few memorable action scenes Terminator 3 disappointed me with a lazy script, bad acting, many bland action scenes and awful character development. With being a hardcore Terminator fan if they called this anything else but Terminator 3 Rise of the Machines, I might have liked it more, otherwise I think the world would have been better without this.

Review title: Not as good as it's predeccesors
Review_body: T3 wasn't an awful movie by any definition of the word, but it wasn't great either. As a stand alone action film it was very good. The action was frenzied and satisfying, and the special effects tremendous. Were it to exist without the compelling lore that T1 and T2 built before it, though, it would be merely average.The TX (the female terminator) was uninspired and boring, and was never alarmingly dangerous as the previous two villians were. She simply didn't scare you, she never seemed unstoppable - which is what the movies were always about when it came to the bad guy: a relentless killing machine that simply can not be stopped, that will never stop, until you are DEAD! Sorry, she wasn't that great. She didn't even look all that great - pretty average looking for a leading female in today's film. And we all know that she was picked to entice young males.....One great highlight of the film was the humor. This movie really made me laugh out loud a few times (as it did the entire audience). Arnold was as good as he ever was, and really looked great for an old guy. You can tell that he loved making this movie.In the end, the plot was as solid as it could be, considering that almost everyone knew what was going to end up happening. The action was killer, as was the special effects. But, it didn't live up to it's mythos. The Terminator is supposed to shock and scare you; the Terminator is suppose to intimidate the audience. The TX did anything but.....8 out of 10 - I would give it a 7 (maybe even a 6), but I realize that it's just an action flick, and you can't expect the world when it comes to that genre. Besides, it's an Arnold movie, and Arnold is the man!

Review title: Good excuse to destroy vehicles - Average movie
Review_body: The crane scene in this movie makes it worthwhile.  I think they tried too hard to compete with the Matrix and failed.  Either that or I am now expecting a good story to go with special effects and it just didn't happen. They also seemed to be trying too hard to set up T4 - I'd probably skip it based on this one.

T3: Rise of the Machines is the 3rd installment of the Terminator series. Though many critics may claim that the absence of director James Cameron may have influenced the style and feel of the movie, I beg to differ, and must add that Jonathon Mostow has done a great job at elevating the depth of the Terminator series fanthom more. Of all the features that this movie displays, its main appeal comes from its level of realism, which adds to its worth in our everyday lives and its influence on various choices and applications that mankind drives to make. The cast is mint, fresh off the shelf (with the exception of Arnold, and on a lighter note, a comic relief Earl Boen, aka. Dr. I'm not Crazy but I am going Crazy). Nick Stahl does an excellent job at fitting the role of John Connor, as he is an highly undescisive character that is not obviously determined to save the world, nor denies his existence, but rather, lives to see himself evolve into the leader of the resistence. Clares Daine does a pretty good job at playing newly introduced and old time childhood friend Brewster, but nothing worth noting.  Arnold? Heck, this guy is unstoppable, since he is essentially, body, mind and soul, the living version of Terminator itself. Unfortunately, Loken, falls a bit short in giving the audience that thriller look. Certainly, she is sexy, sleek and even a bit quirky, but I don't think it was really her fault for her lack of thrillism (invented word), but the castings' fault. All in all, she does give it her best. The first half hour of T3 is sort of an introduction of what John Connor has become since the last installment. John Connor, trying to protect mankind, hides himself from society and becomes a ghost to the world. Not quite, as KAZAAM, TX appears in her little magic ball, etc. etc.. etc... From here on, there is nothing but pure heart-pounding action, and perhaps the greatest scene was the massive 6 car/truck chase b/w TX, T Model 101, Connor and Brewster. The effects in this movie puts Matrix and its successors to shame. It just goes to show that to make something look real, it ought to be real. Anyhow, that's my 2 cents. I give this installment 4/5 stars (relative to 4/5 stars for T2 and 4.5/5 stars for T1).

Review title: Out of this world special effects
Review_body: I just have to say, if you are a fan of action movies, go and see this one. It's a step above almost all "heavy action" movies I've seen in awhile. I would highly recommend going and seeing this at the theater to experience it to its max.As far as the story goes, I think it's pretty hard to come up with a great story/script with 2 already great films preceding it.I think they did a great job and will highly recommend this to all action seekers. Go to a theater with THX certification and listen to the sound system get a serious workout.

Review title: To use the played out saying, it was an "action-packed movie"
Review_body: Though the movie was entertaining, full of humorous quips by Arnold, and lots of explosions and action, it still lacked the same suspense that was present in the first two films.  The action was great, and if you look at the trivia, there was one scene they were going to cut because of cost and running behind budget, but Arnold lowered his price tag by a million so they could do the shot.  It was well worth the million.  Overall, if you've seen the first two, don't expect the same ratios of action and dialogue, but it is still a good movie, and well worth the matinee price I paid for it ;-).

Again we see Arnold as a good guy in Terminator 3, which has too damn much of "great effects". Though the movie was good, but if the director doesn't trust on his own abilities to create a good movie, he shouldn't fill it up with computer-stuff.

Review title: No where near as good as the first two movies.
Review_body: This is one unnecessary sequel to two science fiction classics. Sure, everyone wanted  a another Terminator movie, but they should have giving us more than this. James Cameron is no where in sight in this follow up, and is replace with Jonathan Mostow, whose films Breakdown and 'U-571'were tepid at best. Arnold Schwarzenegger is back as The Terminator who returns to protect an adult John Conner from an advance model-killing machine called the T-X played by Kristanna Loken. Every thing that was set up before in Terminator 2 is throng out for the sake of another sequel, and the story is not only incoherent but also down right annoying in certain parts of the film.  The T-X is not as advance as the T-1000 from Terminator 2, and not as menacing. You were actually scared of The T-1000, and it gave you a reason to be scared by the way that it could kill at will. The T-X is just poor carbon copy of the T-1000, and not as efficient of a killing machine. The story should have been better and should have been a great continuation of the second movie but in it's journey to be different, it forgot what it should have been.  Sure, it's a great time waster but compared to the others, it's a disappointment. The movie was made to capitalize and two much better films and judging by the way the movie ends, they are going to rape those films even further.

Review title: I actually wanted more of a story
Review_body: Just to let you know, I am a die-hard Terminator fan.  Have been ever since the 1st movie.  I collect the comics and have read all the T2 books by S. M. Stirling (like T2: Infiltrator).  I actually wanted more a story than I got in T3.  There is no doubt T3 is a great action movie, and who doesn't love the female Terminator?  But I guess I did miss the Sara Connor character. In T3, John Connor came across as too much of a wimpy cry baby.  The Sara Connor from T2 would have continued to train John on how to survive "Judgment Day".  Overall I was a little disappointed in T3.  To me it was too short (barely 100 minutes), I wanted a more developed story line (like what was happening in the future and that sort of stuff), and I wanted Linda Hamilton back.  I will end up buying the T3 DVD when it comes out, and I can only hope they make a T4, so we can see how the war against the machines really ends.

Review title: The Best Movie Of 2003 And By A Land Slide
Review_body:
After all the garbage I've seen this summer (The Matrix Reloaded, Hulk, and X-Men 2), I was glad to finally see a good movie (Terminator 3). Not only was Terminator 3 good, it was one of the best movies I've ever seen. The story was great, the Terminatrix was awesome (better then the T-100), the action was intense, the ending was perfect, and Arnold was funny as hell.Terminator 3 is by far the best movie of 2003 and it will still be the best movie of 2003 when the year is over. Even Return Of The King won't beat it and Return Of The King is sure to be one of the best movies ever made.There was one thing missing from Terminator 3 and that was the Terminator music. It was played during the end credits but who know why they left it out during the entire movie. If Terminator 3 has the Terminator music, I would actually say that Terminator 3 was perfect. Getting over this minor fault, Terminator 3 easily made it on to my top 10 movies of all time list. This is saying a lot since 8 out of the other 9 of them are from the 80's or earlier.As much as I love Terminator 3, Terminator 2 is slightly better. Terminator 2 makes it one place higher then Terminator 3 on my top 10 movies of all time list. This is due to it being a longer movie and having the Terminator music played quite a few time through out it. Neither one of these things is a big deal but it helped me decide which movie I liked better.
If you haven't seen Terminator 3 already then do yourself a favor and see it right away. If you have seen Terminator 3 and didn't like it then see it again because you obviously missed something.

(Spoilers ahead)Anyone expecting this film to build on the T1 and T2 legacy (I was) will be disappointed. However, the film as its own entity is one of the best action films released in a long time.Looking back, it seems inevitable that T3 should go this route. In T1 we had genuine fear and desperation as the "unstoppable" terminator stalked its prey. In this respect T2 sold out the original for the sake of a good action film packed full of special effects. Admittedly T2 had a good plot including addressing the destiny/fate dilemma and the hope/despair of mankind's future. So where then will T3 go? Risk going back to the gritty original and alienate all the T2 fans? I think not.T3 moves forward into the action genre. Big fights, fancy weapons, glittering effects - none of these disappoint. The plot gets too caught up in the "it's your destiny" loop and doesn't really explore any of the time dilemmas. The ending is inevitable but leads us nicely on to T4.So, given the drawbacks mentioned above, did I like the film? The answer is a resounding "yes". Once I realised that this film should be treated as a *Terminator Action Franchise* I sat back and lapped it up. On leaving the cinema and felt contented that I had been well entertained for 2 hours.I must take a paragraph to talk about the humour in this film. This IS a funny film. While not normally a fan of dumb humour, I did laugh out loud at several points. The dead-pan deliver given by Arnie is excellent and well-timed and fitted well with the feel of the movie.In summary, you must watch this film if you like action movies with interesting storylines. It's entertainment without being an over-the-top action flick a la John Woo. Throughly enjoyable and recommended. 8/10.

Action movies usually don't manage to develop a deep and interesting storyline. And most of them don't even want to. That is fine, since there are a lot of people who like to watch an easy entertaining movie once in a while."Terminator 2: Judgment Day" proved that action movies can be so much more. Sometimes it would seem to you that incredible special effects don't let any financial room for a script (see "Waterworld"), but T2 had it all: Awesome directing, award-winning special effects, a very becoming soundtrack, actors who did an incredible job (Linda especially) and a story that made it my all time favorite.That is why Terminator 3 fails. The team might have produced a decent action movie a la "Predator", but in this case, they hit a whole franchise right in the face. The soundtrack is boring, the movie goes against principles that the first two laid out, the Terminator acts ridiculous, the pictures are nothing compared to the most of the time impressive and artistic scenes from T2.Makes one wonder.. why was this movie even made? The ONLY reason is profit. I know that the goal of every movie is to make money, but if you can feel that there's no love for the project involved, it's crap. There are people who say it is not fair to compare T3 to T2, but what else would you do with a direct sequel?

My girlfriend and I spoke to a friend before seeing this movie, and he said he did not like it. But, trusting the 7.2 vote it recieved from IMDB, we chanced it--and thank God we did. This has got to be the best action movie I've seen in years. We loved it. Some other friends said that there was a more humorous side to it, so I went into the movie expecting a hammed up version of its predessosor; however, the "comedic" scenes just added to the entertainment of the movie, they did not detract from it's seriousness that the end of the earth as we know is near. The ending was fantastic and added more intrigue to the idea that machines will rule the earth and fight mankind for its rule. Moreover, the ending left you with a feeling similar to reading The Stand, or War of the Worlds. A great movie that's worth full price. Bravo! Arnold. I'm looking forward to T4!

T3 outdid itself with a winning combination of state-of-the-art special effects and dry humor.  There wasn't a lot of background for those who haven't seen the previous two, but if you have, you don't need it.  This movie plays up to all the camp developed in the previous two movies and does it quite well.  There are lines that might seem predictable but they are still very funny when delivered, as well as a few new destined-to-be-classics. The mass destruction is so over-the-top that you can't take it seriously, yet it's still exciting.  I had a great time at this movie.

I think one of the best things about about T3 was Kristanna Loken, even if she did have less lines and things to do than the other evil terminators, she still did very very well with what she was given. Personally I think she did a great job. If they make a T4 I hope she is in it but with a bigger role. I also thought that Nick Stahl was quite good. He seemed to come across as quite vunerable though which I wasn't expecting and after a few years on the run you'd think he'd be a little less naive (for lack of a better word). All in all I really loved this movie, I saw it twice in the cinema and would go again if I could. I can't wait for the DVD, I'd like to see some deleted scenes... maybe there were a lot of ones that Kristanna had that were deleted which would explain why she wasn't as scary as the other evil ones. Actually because she had less to do I felt her character more as a "human" than a terminator. She really did try to get her missions done and she did manage to kill the other leaders so she wasn't all bad. And for someone who hasn't done any major body training in a while, Arnie toned up pretty good, but if they get around to making a fourth film... if the timing is going the same way it has been (one a decade) hes going to be more than 65 years old by the time they make it! Claire Danes could have had more of a role... and I really want to know, in the trailer, what's the name of the music right before the end? I think it's the third piece of music to be played (when Kristanna is programming the robot) because I like that piece of music very much.

T3 is a very very fun action movie with a great story congruent with the rest of the Terminator series. A few things could have been done better such as the music and some of the picture; nonetheless it was a great film. Best movie of the year (2003) for me so far because it leaves you with little to think about after it's done. When you finish watching the movie your left with some real funny impressions from it, rather than with some fishy existentialism theory or weird feelings that make your head spin.10/10 - just for being the best this year

Terminator 3 is just like any other 3rd sequel which has been wrongly done because of its director. Jonathan Mostow just sucked the life of this film, cause James Cameron made the 2 other movies into a humanistic type of movie. This film typically destroyed the Terminator franchise all because of the poor directing and the characters are just freaking stubborn.As well as they did not need to make the third one, since the 2nd movie stopped judgement day. The ups of this film is that Arnie is back for good. Like all the other Terminator blockbusters this had romping action. Unfortunately, in every scene it dies down and goes to useless talk about Brewster and Connor. I do feel bad about this film since it already had the quality of an action blockbuster. Unless it was part of a trio of movies. Still entertaining, but nonetheless poor acting and extremely non- Terminator filming makes this movie a 5/10 in my vote. This movie does suck a lot.

I will not accept this as the official sequal to James Camerouns two masterpieces! Brad Fiedels perfect music score to the two previous movies are gone and so is the very soul of the movie. The mood of the movie changes as fast as Nick Stahls eye colour. this movie is not a succesful ending of the terminator trilogy!

As a big fan of the Terminator movies, 1 and 2 were superb! Unfortunately, T3 suffers from the "Hollywood blockbuster" syndrome, the need to out perform and surpass its predecessors with bigger, bolder, more blast-worthy action. Chases and nitroglycerine abound in this film as characterization is pushed to the background.To be fair, very little characterization is needed except for the Claire Danes character. Unless you've been living in an isolated commune for the past 20 years, you know the Terminator. Arnold's persona has become pop culture myth -- like the Six Million Dollar Man writ large. Stahl's character, John Connor, is still the ordinary man tormented by his awesome destiny.T3 does deliver the stunts, the explosions, even the catchy one-liners to which we've become accustomed. Arnold's performance is stellar. His charm breathes humanity into an automaton (Gov. Schwarzenegger one day perhaps?). Stahl is competent, while Danes is immeasurably underused. Note her role as Juliet in Baz Luhrman's Romeo and Juliet -- but hey, this isn't Henry James. Kristanna Loken is good as well, sexily exuding VERY homicidal tendencies.I agree with Roger Ebert in saying that T3 is really a dumbed down version of its history. Were it not for the creative ending, I probably wouldn't have been as impressed. That said, T3 is a worthy addition to the franchise.

Seriously? They ruined what could've been an amazing film series. This, to me, is nothing but a rip off of T2, just different terminator. John Connor is just flat out pathetic in this movie. Both the acting and the action flat out sucked. It was seriously like watching Judgment Day again with a few changes. I also hated how they didn't explain Skynet spawning when the end of T2 changes the fate of the machines taking over. It's weird how Edward Furlong played a better Connor than this shi**y-ass actor did. All I can say is that Arnold's return as the T-101 is the only thing i enjoyed about this garbage. I was so disappointed.

Review title: Great blood & guts movie in the true terminator style!
Review_body: For all the guys out there that want adrenaline pumping blood and guts movie with Arnie doing his thing, this movie is for you. I really enjoyed the movie and loved the effort put into the action scenes. The car chase in particular was awesome. I hope this is not the last terminator movie. I would like to see the story move on from the Rise of the machines to the Terminator 4 The war against the machines. I'm sure there is a lot that can be put into such a movie as this story unlike many think is definitely not dead! Anyway, if you like action movies, this is a must see...very entertaining. Go Arnie!

We could almost unanimously agree that Terminator 2: Judgment Day is one of the best action movies ever made. Having established that, I understand that Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines had a high standard to live up to, so it should have been no surprise if it didn't quite reach the level of its predecessor. I've watched T3 twice now, which tells you that it's not entirely the disappointment that sequels often turn out to be. The action sequences definitely rival those of the other movies in the series, and in fact surpass those of many other action flicks, which is made possible by the fact that the characters in the high-speed chase with multiple crashes and explosions are not human and thus can survive any crash. Kristanna Loken is HOT as the Terminatrix. The movie dishes out the characteristic ironies of time travel and glimpses into the future, although none quite as powerful as the revelation in T2 that the Terminator crushed by Sarah Connor in Part 1 became the prototype for the machines that would eventually terrorize humans. It is interesting to see John Connor grown up, living with the paranoia that comes from his experience with the Terminator, and his feelings about his destiny as the leader of the human race. He is not quite the adult John that I pictured after seeing the trash-talking, street-savvy teenager in T2, but I can accept that people may change, especially after a traumatic experience of nearly being killed by a machine. The movie does not forget the more memorable moments of those which came before it, including a variation of "Come with me if you want to live," and the recurring character of Dr. Silberman, although Arnie's delivery of "I'm back" makes me cringe and think that sticking with the good ol' "I'll be back" might have been less cheesy.All in all, it is a good, though not great, movie as long as the viewer remembers that sequels rarely live up to the ones before it, and yet...this film leaves me with a disturbing, unsettling feeling that it should never have happened. It feels like an afterthought, which we all know it wasone last blockbuster in a fading acting career, one last attempt to make some money on the phenomenal franchise. More than that knowledge of Hollywood, however, I feel troubled as a fan of the first two movies and of Sarah Connor. While I understand that Sarah is only a fictional character, this movie seems an insult to her memory. The fact that the Terminators still exist, are still trying to kill her son and take over the world, makes Sarah seem that much more tragic. After watching her nightmares in T2 which portrayed nuclear explosions with horrifying realism, and cheering her on while she overcame the impossible, I cannot stomach the thought that the machines still come into existence and try to take over. It makes me glad that "Sarah Connor" did not live to see this film.In summary...it's a decent movie and worth a couple viewings, but when you go back and watch T2 again, just pretend that T3 never happened.

Review title: I know its about robots, but do they all have to act like it.
Review_body: I like the part when the concrete itself explodes in a ball of flame. Also the part where the machine has feelings, and pounds cars. Oh yeah, remember in T2 where Arnold's line is " I now know why you cry." Sequels. That's why. I loved the first 2 movies but this one just fails to even entertain. Static dialogue and conflicting emotions does not a great movie make. I'm sure everyone got paid well and there's food on the table, that's great, but if the movie industry ever wondered why people pirate movies its so that we don't feel so ripped off when we shell out 15$ for a mistake. The most entertaining part of the movie was counting the explosions with my cousin, cause then we came up with explosion subcategories. Explosions that are caused by realistic existing incendiary devices ie. gas pipelines, and then there's the non realistic ie. dirt and concrete. Apparently concrete and dirt are actually flammable, huh.

Review title: this film doesn't exist its really a video game
Review_body: this film is the biggest disappointment ever .even worse than ....resident evil .there I've said it ..they should have had Paul WS Anderson write it because he has a habit of botching things up .....man i hate it when filmmakers do this ......utter rubbish ..sheer and utter rubbish if u are a huge terminator fan then boycott this and if u have already seen it then u feel my pain as well.man this is a terrible movie ...i cant even go into detail about how bad it is because its that bad. and now I'm just going say how much i hate Paul WS Anderson because he is evil and i don't like him or his "artistic" views. man if there were a law against making bad movies he would definitely go to jail. i hope hes tried and hanged at dawn.

Review title: I could've waited longer to see this
Review_body: When you watch T1 then T2 you "hope" no one will attempt to make another sequel unless they can match 1 and 2. Unfortunately T3 does not meet this line, in many areas. 1st - there's too many jokes for Terminator where it should have been left out. 2nd - Not being sexist but a female Terminator having a fight with the Terminator doesn't go well she should have been a support character or something and we could have seen some excellent fight scenes. Although her character was made to be "tougher" than the Terminator it still makes you laugh. I see this as a serious movie not one where you crack some jokes - not at least at the Terminator's expense.On a positive note this may set up a base for T4 and hopefully someone may bring it back to level we know it as.......The movie is enjoyable but for me, not as 1 and 2.

lacks any of the moody atmosphere of the first two movies. The director was just going through the motions. The guy who played John Connor was terrible. The characters lacked any depth at all. The idea of having a female terminator was just too gimmicky. Too many plot holes, out and out rip offs from the first two films and lack of originality makes me wonder what Arnie was thinking, reprising his role for this joke of a film. This film seems to have focused more on generating revenue than completing a classic film trilogy. There is a complete lack of substance and will only appeal to the lowest common denominator. Those who can't see past the one liners will probably enjoy it. Fans of the first two films who enjoyed the story as a whole and the world in which it took place will be aghast at the rather lame attempt at making a good film.

This film is a complete tour de force of wacky, out-there and not least of all CHILDISH comedy! from the very first appearance of the iconic and much-beloved action character wearing FRUITY ELTON JOHN SHADES BY MISTAKE!! to the hilarious (and dated!) "talk to the hand" gags, this film's script and execution is chock-a-block full of gut-busting cracks the whole family can enjoy! eschewing the boring old action hero role of both preceding classic movies, nearly every line uttered by comedic mastermind Arnold Schwarzenegger as "the terminator comedy funbot" had the entire theater literally GROANING with laughter. I can only hope that the next entry in this series finally gets rid of all the LAME action sequences that unfortunately got in the way of the gags in this one. I think that dave chappelle, andy dick and paulie shore would be EXCELLENT choices for different terminator models!!! I can just imagine all the potential pratfalls in the futuristic warzone!!

Review title: Pure Action, Without Any Drive, Spirit or Thought Required
Review_body:
I've seen it twice now and have been doing a lot of thinking about what I've observed. I've been trying to figure out what they've done to one of my favorite movie series of all time.T1 was a Sci-Fi thriller with some action thrown in. It was about thought. They couldn't throw out hours of CGI action back in these days. It was up to your imagination to fill in the gaps. It left you wondering just what you were seeing and what was happening. Cameron didn't go out of his way to explain everything or to have explosions everywhere. It was about shadows, symbolism, and dreaming. It was awesome.T2 was the action side of T1 but still with a razor sharp plot that left the viewer thinking hard about what he was seeing. It dealt with issues of humanity and the thought that our lives are not predetermined to work out a certain way. T2, as was T1, was a finely sculpted movie. The only improvement could have been leaving all the DVD's added footage in the theatrical release.T3 is a new and very different monster. Cameron is gone, replaced by Mostow. Mostow created a movie with a different goal, and a very different feeling. The emphasis was plainly on the action with storyline and character development taking a backseat. There weren't really any major flaws with the small amount of story there was, and I liked how it continued T2's "fate is what we make" theme. But, this move just lacks the character and energy of Cameron's Terminator works.For one, the humor was far too excessive. T-800s don't crack jokes. The ONLY reason Arnold did in T2 was because John taught them to him after they switched Arnold's chip to learn mode. A T-800 is a walking AI designed to efficiently and ruthlessly kill. They don't go out of their way to be funny. The worst part of the humor was most certainly the fact that it downplayed the seriousness of the film. The world is about to end, T-800s and T-Xs are trashing citys and gruesomely murdering people. Intertwining humor with this is ridiculous. They seemed to go out of their way to destroy the atmosphere of the movie.One MAJOR peeve for me was the lack of a quality soundtrack. Music is a major part of this series, and a soundtrack easily makes or breaks a movie for me. Brad Fiedel's score for T1 and T2 are indisputably legendary and are easily 50% of what made the movies so great. They had an edge to them that fit with the whole evil machine theme, and created a simply stunning sonic atmosphere. His use of industrial sounds to create a moving, percussion-based sound was just incredibly creative.This new Marco Beltrami fellow decided to take the Terminator his own direction. Too bad his direction is a muddy, unemotional mess. Perhaps he is a T-800, his music inspired the same level of emotion in me as the T-800 displays. Watching the city-block smashing scene without any influential background music was just completely illusion-breaking and dumbfounding. The theme for the T-X was uninspired and very weak. Arnold's hammer-banging heavy industrial theme from T2 was replaced with nothing as far as I could tell. The poor score made the movie feel like a halfway effort. The music lacked heart, and thus so did the visuals.After seeing it a second time I've become sort of less critical, however. A sequel means changes, and I realize that. The new director did a decent job maintaining consistency with the Terminator plotline. He just couldn't knit together the atmosphere, story, emotion, and action that made the older two flicks such total classics.A special message for Mostow: Bring back Brad Fiedel to score T4.
C+

This was a good (not great) movie to just sit and watch.  The action was pretty good but I did expect more. I left the movie thinking it was only intermission. The final duel should have been longer and the slapping over the head hinting to another movie takes away form the overall ending.  Is T4 already in production?

For all of you who are interested in renting out this movie, I recommend you do it with the lowest expectations.Here are some spoilers: 1)  it's an exact copy of #1/#2 I mean, they even use the SAME EXACT PHRASES to try and get you nostalgic for the first 2 movies (which were awesome)2)  The plan/strategy is not cohesive/inconsistencies in plot: First they are going to protect the other members of the resistance, then they don't and they let them die. Other problems:  Why not send back terminators to just search for John Connors--even if they don't know where he is now?  And why is this version of this terminator (terminatrix) is so stupid (speeding on highways, etc.)? And why not go back to an earlier date (again) to get John Connors?
There are a lot more spoilers, but I don't want to take away all the fun...Seriously, do yourself a favor and just wait until there is no other movie you want to see before wasting your time here.

Review title: buy T-2 and save your money
Review_body: Pretty lame. They took the best parts of T-2 and recycled them, even down to the fight choreography, truck chase, opening scene, well you get the idea. John Conner was WEAK. If you like the originals you are probably going to see it anyway but at least go during a bargain matinee.James Cameron where in the heck are ya?Alan Francis,actor

All I can say is that this movie kicked ass!  Probably the best of the 5 summer movies I have seen so far.However, If you guys own the Ultimate Edition DVD of T-2, watching the Special Edition cut with the extra scenes featuring the Sarah Connor character as an old woman will not make this 3rd part make sense.Overall, fantastic sequel....A-....Looking forward to the conclusion.

Review title: Not as good as I thought it could be...
Review_body: I liked the movie as a stand alone but, as the third in a series I thought it was seriously flawed. Terminator and T2 were serious movies about the end of the world due to mans insistence of technology and machines. This third movie was spattered with one-liners referring back to the previous two - it made a comedy of it. The acting and effects however were excellent and I thought the movie was well presented. This movie was not really for the fans of the previous Terminator movies but I'm sure it will be very popular to those new to the 'Terminator' storyline. I hope the story will continue.

Review title: "Anyone expecting something special is gonna have a real bad day get it!."
Review_body: The first TERMINATOR remains my favorite film ever. The second is right up there. So as far as film going goes these films mean a lot to me. Is it just me or are big films getting worse by the month. Even with hints of decent stories pictures are so rushed now. Special effects, BOOM, special effects, JUMP CUT, F/X GALLORE, BOOM...THE END.I miss the days of the eighties action flicks. Even the early nineties hung in there a bit with TOTAL RECALL, TERMINATOR 2 (despite its morality) and NATURAL BORN KILLERS. My point is these films the good ones, the intense action ones...the fun ones all stuck with violence. Shying away from violence teaches us guns and explosions lack consequence. Not to mention it's all fantasy. We're being taught not to have imagination.The evolution of film ceases to exist. Technology needs to complement not substitute a story (a la MATRIX RE-LOADED and Terminator 3). Hopefully M. Night or Peter Jackson, or some kid at home writing a great story will inspire us.

Review title: "Anyone expecting something special is gonna have a real bad day get it."
Review_body: The first TERMINATOR remains my favorite film ever. The second is right up there. So as far as film going goes these films mean a lot to me. Is it just me or are big films getting worse by the month. Even with hints of decent stories pictures are so rushed now. Special effects, BOOM, special effects, JUMP CUT, F/X GALORE, BOOM...THE END.I miss the days of the eighties action flicks. Even the early nineties hung in there a bit with TOTAL RECALL, TERMINATOR 2 (despite its morality) and NATURAL BORN KILLERS. My point is these films the good ones, the intense action ones...the fun ones all stuck with violence. Shying away from violence teaches us guns and explosions lack consequence. Not to mention it's all fantasy. We're being taught not to have imagination.The evolution of film ceases to exist. Technology needs to complement not substitute a story (a la MATRIX RE-LOADED and Terminator 3). Hopefully M. Night or Peter Jackson, or some kid at home writing a great story will inspire us.It's not all about violence but if you have menacing characters. Please make them convincing.I wish the Girl-inator beautiful as she was would've kicked some more ass. She arrived only to kill some 50 year old Beverly Hills woman. She should came like Arnold in number one and messed up some gangsters or something. Cliche maybe so, but would've been better than over used one liners and crap.

Review title: After all the negative reviews, it surprised me.
Review_body: Let me first tell you what expected; not much. Everybody said it "sucked".So after seeing the "hit movies of the summer" (X-Men 2, Matrix reloaded, Hulk, etc) I thought X2 was the only "OK" movie.Boy, was I wrong.Ok, so it might not be totally 110% accurate. There might be a couple of gaps in the story. And the effects in few scenes might make you go "Ok, this is CGI, and not even good one". But... T3 was a movie, that made me go "whoa, back up, take a break". The action started from the moment the movie started, and stopped about 5 minutes before the end credits, and the movie gave the watchers ample opportunity to go "ok, let me figure out this part of Terminator story/history, before you give it away in a few minutes".It might not be the best script, nor the best acting (by a long shot, Mr. Governor), but it sure as he is one hell of a rollercoaster ride of action and explosions. And the story stays true enough to please a long time Terminator fan (especially the dark ending).I can wouch that the DD5.1 track on the DVD is well and truly used... ;)

When I first heard about Terminator 3, I was ecstatic. I have loved the first two films ever since I was a child (my older brother's watched them a lot). But when I heard that James Cameron was dropping out, and that John Connor wouldn't be played by Edward Furlong I was a little disapointed, but still excited. However, I was right to be disapointed. Terminator 3 is a good movie in general, but compared to the first two movies, it's crap. There are some OK moments, most movies have them, and even I thought the beginning part with the sunglasses was funny, but the movies aren't made to be funny. They aren't made to mock the first two. The only thing I really liked *****SPOILER***** was seeing the psychiatrist (Dr. Peter Silberman) from the first two films. The ending was also very depressing. If Judgment Day comes anyway, what were the first two films for?************Anyways, I think that they should have left the Terminator franchise alone. Big budget movies, do not always make good films.

Review title: Not the worst, but not great either
Review_body: Aside from this movie being very campy compared to its predecessors, the end was very emotional. My biggest beef with the plot is when the T-850 tells John and Kate that he was the one who killed John in the future because of the resemblance to the model from T-2. Am I really supposed to believe the savior of the future and leader of the Resistance would be stupid enough to make that mistake? Come on.

Review title: This movie had so much potential to fail, but it doesn't.
Review_body: Matrix who, I didn't need my dictionary for this one.  It was cool, such a well structured film that seamed fluidly.  And actually had a story line too.  Everything blended so well, from the extreme stunts & graphics to the story & one liners.

Review title: The best action movie, the matrix trilogy should take notes
