This film feels like they just wanted to cash in on the 'sequels/trilogies' thing going on right now.Some of the special effects were okay, but once again poor C.G.I. (like Hulk) ruined what could of been a great film. None of these people should work in Hollywood again! If they do, don't let them anywhere near sequels/trilogies because they will ruin them, like they have done here.
This movie was better than I thought. It's not any of those so called "deep movies" named by the experts but I really enjoyed this one. Action is all I wanted and I got it!

Review title: Another beloved TradeMark has been exploited...
Review_body: Does the following two statements apply to you?Terminator - "I liked it alot".Terminator 2 - "I loved it, it excelled in a superior manner."If you answered "yes", then you will not like Terminator 3, and in truth you would be better off not seeing it. By not seeing it, you will preserve the memory of the two previous movies without tainting them. Should you despite this warning choose to view T3, then please note that you will never again be able to view the previous movies without conjuring up the ghosts of T3.Are you thinking "it can't be that bad, this person just didn't understand it"?I too thought along this line when prewarned about it, I imagined that it had to have some entertaining qualities given it being a Terminator movie. Movies like that just aren't all-out bad.I was wrong, I should have listened to the person who warned me.Right about now you are thinking "I refuse to be the only person on the planet to not have seen T3, simply because of a warning on IMDB."Again, if the top two rows apply to you, then you will wish you had listened to this warning.Are you thinking "this person is some kind of pro critic or really picky about movies, I just want to see what happened after T2"?No, I am not a professional critic, and I'm probably not more picky about movies than you. And yes, I sure wanted to see what happened after T2. But you see, you do not get to see what happened after T2, because the people responsible for that excellent script did not touch a page of this movie. It is entirely different. The company which made T2, Corolco, didn't produce this movie. Cameron did not co-write nor produce this movie.T3 is riddled with large caliber logic and story holes, many things don't add up and contradict the "Terminator world". The cast is really ill chosen, the T-X technology a bit too much for me, but the bottom line is that it doesn't have much of a story. Many movies don't actually need one, take "Deep Blue Sea" for instance, great entertainment without the need of a solid story. But the T movies already have a very cool story with, mostly, down-to-earth technology involved. Advanced, but mostly believable, and this goes for design also, the whole "make it look cool" clause from the first T2 book was very appealing to me as I enjoy things which look nice but also look practical enough to pass as a believable design. T3's tech and design is a bit different, clearly shown with both with the T-X and hardware in the 2029 scenes.Let me make it blatantly clear what we are talking about here. This will be fully understood by fans of the Aliens saga. I rank T3 as marginally better than "Alien : Resurrection", a movie which corrupted and devastated the the beloved Aliens saga. This statement will allow you to make your own references. If you liked "Aliens : Resurrection" and thought it to be a worthy follow-up to the earlier movies, then you will most probably love T3. If you on the other hand wish it had never come to exist, then you get an idea of my views on T3.I remember going to see "Alien 3" many years ago, I then expected something even better and more advanced than the prequel before it, I was utterly disappointed due to it not measuring up to my expectations. In retrospect, Alien 3 isn't really that bad, just different. I wish I could say the same for T3. I came to the theatre expecting something bad, due to numerous reviews, the intel of T3's budget problems and a script without Cameron. All of this negativity made me confident T3 would come out on top, seeing how I expected so little of it. But the disappointment was devastating. The worst part is that T3 has become a comedy, a quick action movie with dry jokes and one-liners accompanied with solid special effects. The movie mocks the previous two movies and tries to play the same jokes, whereas it comes out as a sad experience. Even the Terminators aren't really the same anymore, they are much more human, with facial expressions and logics that robots would never apply. The whole "machine syndrome" isn't apparent at all, which is one of the really nice things about T2, this "man beside machine, examining the differences and similarities of her creation."While T2's story was excellent, it had something else, call it "storytelling"; the ability to tell a story in a flowing manner with scenes that logically follow eachother and keeps the viewer interested. This technique is one of the prime things that makes T2 excel and the prime thing that makes T3 crash and burn. The viewer is presented with scenes which appear to be cut together, where most are action scenes and the other scenes are dry humor. Humor will vary greatly between people, but as a preview of what to expect, I must say that a joke which was funny when Joe Pesci said it in Lethal Weapon 3, is certainly not funny 2003.I do apologize for the constant comparisons with Terminator and T2, such references do not belong in a review, but I felt it was needed so everyone reading this can examine my views on the previous movies and compare it with their own views. Without references that one can relate to, a review or criticism is simply an incomprehendable description from which it is difficult to form an opinion on.In truth, I do not want you to see T3. Yes, you will be one of the few on the planet who didn't see T3, but then again you will be one of the few people who has untainted, glorious memories of the first two movies. No one can change that.

may contain SPOILERprior too going to see this film in the U.K. i have read several message boards and T-3 really has had a fair number of critics. Though personally i found the film to be superb. Solid acting, and why has no1 else pointed out , Nick Stahl ( john connor) looks so much like Kyle Reece, his father T-1. so even though its a different actor 2 T-2 ( Edward furlong) i still felt it was John connor, unlike in other series of films where the characters are played by different actors. The affects were great, and the pace of the film was a lot better than Matrix reloaded, which  found tedious at points. sorry to mention The matrix, but it is basicly a rip off of terminator, with the added touch of a computerised world. eg THE ONE - John connor - Neo Enemy - the machines - the machines Real world - humans dead, humans deadi wont go on as this is a review for t-3. The only downer id say was the T-X, you dont look at her and think shes a terminator, unlike arnie, back to what hes best at, playing " THE TERMINATOR". People have moaned about there being too much comedy in this film, but come on with 3 billion deaths on the way, you need something to lighten things up a bit, Cameron would not have had the balls to end T-3 like that, he didnt even have the balls to make T-3, so mostow deserves more credit than hes being shown. Me personally i liked the storyline how everything linked up, i didnt watch it thinkin, oh thats a coincidence. i believed everything was down to fate. great film, enough said, 10/10

This movie is the sequel to `The Terminator' and `Terminator 2.' The rise of the machines has more explosions, more action, and a better plot than the earlier two films. Terminator 3 `Rise of the Machines' is directed by Jonathon Mostow. The movie is about machines that look like people sent from the future to protect or kill John Connor (Nick Stahl). The machines are called terminators. The terminator that is sent back to keep John Connor alive is well acted by Arnold Schwarzenegger. The big difference with this movie is that the terminator is not just sent back in time to protect the beloved John Connor, but is there to protect Kate Brewster (Claire Danes). The reason is because Kate and John are supposed to get married in the future and later their children will become important to mankind.John Connor is important, because he is to protect the world from the machines. He becomes the leader of the people. On the day of the ending of the world, as we know it, is very close, and he will save the people that are left. The movie has another terminator called the T-X (Kristanna Loken). She is the perfect hot chick to play the part of a terminator. She is sent back in time to kill John Connor and all of his lieutenants. The plot has thickened; John and Kate must survive to ensure the survival of mankind in the future. I believe this movie is better than the first and second films.

Review title: A little less action a little more conversation?
Review_body: This film was almost as good a sequel to T2 without Jim Cameron.  What would have made it perfect would have been Edward Furlong playing Connor (the producers still haven't given an adequate excuse for this).  Also a little more conversation a little less action would have helped.

This movie was little more than an attempt at Hollywood to make more money out of the idea.  Yes, what made T1 and T2 great was the story.  T3 had no story and no emotion.For a start, John Connor sure got ugly in twelve years (sorry nick stahl). Secondly I think Sarah Connor would have had to have been shot before she would die.If Fans of T1 and T2 want to continue the ride, forget T3, go and buy the great novels by S.M Stirling.

Overall I liked it better than T2. The acting was better, the special effects were par, and the script was better. It hits more than it misses.My only complaint would be the TX, which wasn't as interesting or as well done as the T-1000 (of T2). But Arnold's T-101 was much better this time out, and the movie was much improved by losing the 'punk kid' version of John Conner and Sarah Conner's character.One of the better Arnold movies, and a worthy Terminator sequel.

at last a trilogy that didn't let me down!!! i now regret not seeing this at the cinema and wish i hadn't pinned all my hopes on the matrix, which alas should have been left as just one of the greatest one off films ever!!! but will there be a forth with arnie doing the government thing?!?!  please get him back for it if there is and not some substitute like the rock. who posseses the acting qualities of um, er, well, a rock?!?!

Review title: The art of story telling has died a death here
Review_body: As a fan of the series since I saw the first one at the cinema this film was a massive disappointment. I own the DVD's and have watched them many times.There has been a trend over the last few years to substitute a well worked script for lots of actions shots and this film just about represents the pinnacle of this type of movie making. I was saddened by it. What a waste of an opportunity to finish off the series on a high note.As a technical achievement it is exceptional but the script is flat and lifeless. It seems that James Cameron's part in producing the script must have been very small or he's lost the plot. Add in second rate music (the first two having first rate music!) and the result is all gloss and no substance.Sure this type of film is all about a action but it does need a good script to work well. Just adding in bigger explosions and more carnage just ain't the way to do it.Such a disappointment, I really wanted to enjoy this film.

Review title: I love James Cameron and all...
Review_body: ...but the fanboys have taken it just a wee far with the hatred for this film.I have been a fan of this series since I first saw the original in 1984 at the age of two. My love for all things Ah-Nuld continues to this day. "Rise Of The Machines" definetly has flaws... but nothing overly glaring in my opinion (with the exception of the whole "talk to the hand" bit).Top notch action (no denying the utter sweetness of that first chase in downtown L.A.), impressive visuals, and a solid story. It may not have alot in the way of character development ... mainly because there's never much time for any of the characters to be sitting still for more than a few minutes.The feeling of this movie is very urgent. Lots of chasing and little to no pausing. Very quick pacing -- even more so than the other films in the series. Characters are ALWAYS in motion.I have been waiting since July 91 for another installment -- and I really believe this is a worthy entry in a great series of films. It may not be as memorable as the first two... but its still much more entertaining than alot of the action dreck that comes from Hollywood now-a-days.The Terminator - 8/10Judgment Day - 9/10Rise Of The Machines - 7/10

The third film in the franchise would be quickly forgettable if not for it's ability to depress and disappoint fans of the originals. What feels like more of a spoof than a genuine addition to the previous films is full of genuinely unfunny "jokes", huge plot holes, and unimaginative scenes shamelessly recycled from James Cameron's previous work. Somehow the Director manages all of this while at the same time avoiding any thought provocation and emotional content, something viewers tend to overlook in the previous films, even despite the dark subject matter of impending nuclear holocaust, inevitable unchangeable fate (which in itself contradicts the message well delivered in the second film of free will and writing one's own future), soulless killing machines hell-bent on murdering individuals, etc. Indeed despite all these gripping themes (hijacked from the previous films and not the directors own work), the director only manages to present to us an uninspired ret-con of the story presented. Where before we are told the terminator cannot learn in order to limit his free will, the terminator in this film shows clear signs of learning and imagined "wit" as he spouts one liners in a way unfitting of a killing machine. I don't see this as actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, who clearly does his best to play his quintessential role in the face of terrible direction. This new terminator is presented as something to be laughed at in funny situations, as in the scene where he takes his clothes from the male stripper, and is somehow stripped of all that made him menacing even as the hero of the second film. The female villain of this film was full of emotion, sexiness, and wit, which only serves to discredit her as a terminator. She clearly enjoys killing, and her only defining feature is turning her arm into an assortment of guns, one trick to an otherwise unimaginative pony. John Connor neither resembles nor acts like he did in the previous film, and comes across as a loser. Despite this, he does somehow manage to expertly activate a particle collider in one bodged scene. His new romantic interest is of so little importance or character I won't waste your time writing about her.All in all, Terminator fans should probably avoid this disappointing film.

Review title: A Good movie with much action and special effects
Review_body: HuiiiTerminator 1 and 2 where also great, and I've waited for part 3. When I saw it I liked this movie very much. Many Action and special effects are there in this movie. The story line isn't as great as Terminator 2. But there's more action. I've didn't expect it so good, because John Conner was another actor and James Cameron wasn't in it. But I didn't think he could do a better job. The only thing I think is that the TX isn't better then the t-1000.8/10Piet

Don't believe all the negative comments about this movie. It's a great movie! Excellent action and a well written script. It's not a James Cameron movie. I think it's better than a Cameron movie. More interesting to watch and not as manipulative as his movies. I always feel a bit fooled the second time I watch one of his movies because they suddenly feel so empty. All the splendor is gone. T 3's main characters actually feel like humans - not like the caricatures that Cameron tend to rely on. The movie also has a nice Japanese feel to it. There's both drama, fun and serious action in a good combination. Excellent photo, effects and editing. I'll give it 4 of 5.

John Connor. Fighter for the human race against the evil terminating machines. Taken out right at the beginning by a cute little DEER in the road. I think that tells me pretty much what I'm in for. A movie thats going to take me 4-5 days to finish watching. If I make it that far.

That was the best film of the Terminator series and one of the best 10 movies i have ever watched... The differences from the previous parts were;1-The technology was used more as the new terminator could get into the net by a cellular phone,2-It was wanted to attract attention to the weight of Terminator as 1 tone.3-Scenes were harder than the previous ones,4-The developments on the movie were as parallel as the real life and the technology from the first movie at 1984 to the last part at 2003..One scene had a mistake; terminator came by the pickup and saved Kate with kicking the other terminator,and crashed into the pet clinics' building,but the explosion was at 10 meters left from the crashing..that was comic..although this I am waiting for the 4th of the series..

Review title: 2 years on.... and this has set the low standard for sequels
Review_body: We have all seen how a few companies can set up the "milking" wagon. Nevlada, Disney, Microsoft. But here is another example of how one film defined the "low standard" of media. T3: Rise of the machines or should that be T3: The Unneeded sequel.My brother got this as a Christmas present 2 years back. He thought it was alright and i thought the same thing. But that was 2 years ago...It seems to hit me (especially after watching T2, though not all of it) that their never was meant to be a sequel, the story was already closed, finished, done. So why did somebody continue the story when James Cameron, already finished it? We might not know the answer to that, but one things for sure, it set the "low milking standard" for films like xXx 2, 2 Fast 2 Furious and Batman and Robin. Just like the companies i stated above.And some people enjoy the miking wagon? If you are going to see this, DON'T! Watch T2 and consider the story closed.

The Terminator, which was released in 1984 was spectacular for its time. Although, some of the special effects may seem outdated today, it is still an outstanding movie. It told the story of Sarah Connor and how her son would one day be the leader of the world resistance against the machines that have taken over the world, the last chance for human survival. A Terminator (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is sent back to 1984 to kill Connor before her son is born, but Kyle Reese (Michael Beihn) is also sent to protect her. It's a simple storyline, but it was still an effective movie. A sequel to this movie was inevitable, thus the spawn of Terminator 2: Judgment Day in 1991. The special effects were better and the story was expanded. This time around, the terminator once again played by Schwarzenegger, is the good guy to protect John Connor, now 13, and the T-1000 is sent to kill him. It was pretty much the same movie, but with bigger and better effects.Even still, both of those movies, directed by James Cameron, are one of the best sci-fi action movies ever made. Jonathan Mostow, director of Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines, could learn a thing or two from him. The original storyline was massacred. The entire theory that "The future is not set" is ignored. It is paraphrased in the opening as "the future is still not written", but the writers forgot about it because from the plot twist at the end, the nuclear war is inevitable. There is no stopping it. So, then, that means that the future is set and there really is no use in trying to change it. "Fate is what we make of it" no longer applies. The writers should've researched the previous Terminator films before starting on the third.What this movie lacks is James Cameron's direction. I give it a six out of ten stars only because of its action and the fact that the villain is now a hot and sexy female robot. I hear a fourth one is in the makings, and this is a mistake. Domestically, this film did not do well, so there is no hope for Terminator 4. I still like this movie because the action genre is my third favorite movie genre. I recommend this movie to any action movie lover, but not for Terminator fans.

OK well, there's not much i can say that hasn't already been posted. i'll not go into detail about all the obvious goofs and down right mistakes! i think everyone feels this film is a big let down in regards to the other films in the series, and i feel the same. i think it's how you feel no emotional connection to the characters, they're just there and gone. do big dramatic, emotional ending to the terminator, it just blows up and the film continues on. and another downfall, which i think was one of the biggest blunders of the film - the TX, an extremely advanced "female" terminator. first of all, a female terminator, nobody wants to see a female terminator being more advanced and stronger than arnie as the t-800. i mean, if this was all real life, i would say the T-1000 was a much deadlier enemy and could take down the TX (who seems rather stupid) no problem. but back to reality. i remember reading about this TX before the film was released and how it could reprogram other terminators and i was thinking, this is a great idea. but what became of it?- the TX reprogrammed the t-800 (which you didn't even see) and it came to get john with a very odd painful expression on its face, but ended up bashing that car to bits - WHAT THE HELL WAS THAT! i don't understand that bit, was it just trying to bash that car until his system was back to normal?? but i think the biggest mistake in this film (for me anyway) the part which when i saw it made some vomit actually come up into my throat was when in the convenience store he actually said - "TALK TO THE HAND" to the clerk. what the sh1t was that all about?! the terminator turns round and shoots the guy, thats whats meant to happen! or at least throws him or somethin! but i suppose that started when he was in the gay bar and he grabbed the guys hand and spoke to it. no bloody start to the film, like the other ones. sadly this is just a basic action film, with no depth. the only good part was the ending. i wont say stay away from it because I'm sure anyone who has seen the first two films will certainly have already seen this. so i'll end this by saying, this film only ralates to the other 2 films by name and by nothing else. i'm giving it 5/10. simply because for an action film it was alright.p.s. does anyone think Paul Verhoeven would direct a good Terminator??

I just watched End of Days and T3 back to back. So much was taken from end of days and put into this movie . Why? End of days was not much of a flop that one can say, "lets take this plot from the movie that no one bothered to watch and put into this one, that we know everyone is going to watch".Too many similarities ruined it for me . Its like I was watching the same movies with more characters and different names at times. I was disappointed. In this Movie our beloved Terminator (Arnie) is not as Human as we last saw it. Honestly , if you have seen the last 45Minutes of "End of Days" or have a knowledgeable idea of what the movie was about, then you have an idea of what this movie is about. I know the temptation of seeing terminator 3 is much stronger than any advice that you'l read or hear. Either way its not a bad movie, buts a movie you at times think you have already seen. Watch it and I hope you enjoy it, just don't go into it thinking or expecting what you saw and learned in T2.

In watching this film i had indeed had high hopes, sadly yes i was disappointed but there is something a story there underneath the surface which had promise. The Terminatrix is an interesting addition to the series, some may say pointless and merely a backwards step, however this is not the case. The Terminatrix is a mixture of both the Terminator models from the first movies and has additional inbuilt weapons would do make for a more powerful enemy. However this is not very well executed and with more work and direction could have been an astounding piece of film folklore in a similar way to the T1000 from T2. The action sequences whilst fun, did not rival the impact of sequences past. This is primarily where the movie fails. With more focus these sequences could have been key in establishing the movie as a must see film. The music score is also passable at best. Whereas in T2 again, the music score built the tension up and made you feel that you were along for the ride as well. In this movie however, you will barely notice that it is there, this is a massive disappointment. The film also is very short, the previous two films being well over 2 hours, this goes little over 1 and a half and feels rushed. The ending of the film however is a shock to the system and a completely UN-Hollywood ending, a very good surprise which leaves the door open if necessary for another sequel. Overall, the ideas are good, with more work and care it could have stood out like its predecessors, however sadly it falls rather flat. Check it out but do not expect more than an average flick.

When I saw the movie the first time, after I watched the first terminator and T2 I wasn't really disappointed by it. It was a good decent movie with a really terrifying terminator and a good plot with interesting new approach to future sequels. I would understand why at the time of the release it was considered a bad followup BUT after I watched the sequels including "dark fate", this movie is a masterpiece and probably the last decent terminator movie to date. In my opinion if you wanna see this movie franchise don't go further than this movie. Even if this movie ends in a sad ending, the sequels are even sadder😢.
Absolutely terrible and shamed the first two FilmsDon't bother

Review title: There is no future without ammo.
Review_body: I find a lot of the comments and flubs mere coincidence compared to the major accidents of intentional filmography and story telling. I have several major arguments with this film, as with many adventure films. How can so many rounds of ammo be fired by alleged professionals and no one gets hit? Why do they throw away expensive gun magazines and guns that run out of ammo, as if it's an old head of cabbage? And, most of all, where do these slim robots carry all the fuel to fly, and all the ammo to fire continuously for 30 seconds? There is never any sign of a fuel tank nor ballistic cache. Will Hollywood please employ an engineer to design these devices instead of an SFX jockey; or worse, a director. As an actor of 35 years, I can faithfully tell you that directors make actors do really stupid things we cannot control unless wealthy enough to have point options. Even Liam Neeson, one of the greatest actors of the 21st century, has a hard time battling directors. Those who get their way: Sharon Stone (on the outs), Julia Roberts (considered mostly bi-polar), Dustin Hoffman (with no debate, he commands), Jeff Goldblum (ad-libbing since inception and basically playing the same Dustin Hoffman/Robert Blake "Let me try to throw the other actor in the scene off balance so that I look great" garbage -- Will Smith beat him in ID4). I can't tell you how many times that kind of sufferage has been pulled on me by another actor/actress. Jeff Goldblume deserves a kick-in-the-crotch lifetime award. Dustin Hoffman deserves a one-man show award. Really. Any performance the man has ever done was a one-man show and he needs to stop harasing the entertainment industry with his single-minded self hero worship. I tell you...; Robert Downey Jr is better than every actor. Truthfully. Drunk, stoned on crack, and a week without sleep, he is better than them all. Why do you think he keeps getting stoned? No challenge.

OK, so critically i'm forced to accept that my one star rating could be seen as maybe a bit harsh, the action was OK after all, the film looked pretty enough and the story was genuinely not as slap-dash and floored as we all dreaded it would be. As a stand alone film i could've genuinely forgiven this movie it's quirky sense of humor and cartoonish action sequences (that comedy 'DUNK' noise when Arnie is hit by a truck whilst riding the forklift truck is pure Wylee Kyote). However, that's where we hit the real meat of my problem with this movie, it's not just any random piece of action pie, it's the sequel to terminator 2, a film which even if you don't consider to be the greatest action movie of all time (which i emphatically do), everyone must agree had a certain iconic, macho appeal and tone. Now i accept that for a fairly unknown director, resuscitating such a beloved and successful franchise after such a long time must've been daunting, and i thoroughly expected to sit back in my comfortable cinema seat and watch with joy as the third terminator strained with mighty, piston-like muscles in an effort to avoid being crushed under the weight of its prequels. So you can begin to imagine my disappointment when rather than standing up to its prequels with its chest puffed out, T3 seemed rather to make a camp hand gesture and prance away. In short, my greatest problem with T3 is not that it isn't as good as its predecessors (i mean what is?), it's that it often feels like you're watching a spoofed remake, an impression not harmed by the fact that T3 'shares' most of its basic plot structure with T2. Case in point would have to be the scene in which the terminator seeks to acquire his trade mark leather jacket ensemble, although in previous films this simply seems to be the first outfit he found, in T3 it seems nothing else would do. You can almost hear the writers laughing and congratulating themselves at their sparkling wit, as the terminator is forced to regurgitate his iconic "i need your clothes, your boots and your motorcycle" line... to a male stripper. And the icing on the cake, when the 'unstoppable killing machine' walks outside and puts on the pair of pink, Elton john-style, star sunglasses: and the writers laugh, and the producers laugh and i die a little bit inside.However, the saddest thing i found, watching this movie was not the horrible, gimmick ridden plotting (ooo... lets make this evil terminator a girl!!!!!) that coated each scene, but the much broader plot-strokes that smashed into the terminator mythology like a certain hanging steel girder into a certain skull. Killing off Sarah Conner (the only woman ever created who could've kicked Lt. Ripley's ass) off screen no less, shifting the credit for saving mankind from John Conner (who's become a pussy instead of a super-soldier) to 'his wife?!?'. Its these massive blows that seem to have crippled a franchise that always seemed to have one last movie in it.However, i must freely admit that to most people this movie represents a small slice of action escapism that should warrant at least an hour and a half of you time if not your thoughts. But for me, and anyone else who bothered to learn to spell 'mimetic polyalloy' it's like watching a once proud bear being made to dance in a dirty tutu for the mild amusement of its owners.I always maintain that T2 was one of the saddest movies i've ever seen, at least in that way T3 managed to emulate it.

Now this movie was alright. The action was good, the music had that terminator feel to it, and Arnold can still kick some ass. But the plot is starting to get old. Whiney John Connor is still complaining that his life sucks and that it is going to end with judgment day. Well duh!!! we figured that out in the last movie. Then there is the TX. My god, what a way to attract movie viewers. The director and writer must have been thinking "this movie needs something raunchy, something hard core. Hey i know! BOOBIES. Even better, boobs in a hot tight leather jacket." My friends came walking out of the theater saying the best part was when the bitches boobs expanded to a triple e cup. Plus the ending is sour.Everyoneknows judgment day is coming, why over dramatize it? Everyone knows that kate and john are going to win the war against the goddamn machines. This whole movie was a wasted opportunity. They should have gone with a whole new plot that involved something different than judgment day and a female terminator. So I am asking nicely directors and writers, if there ever is a T4, think about us, the fans, and how much we will despise you if you make another T3.

This is what happens when you hand over a perfectly good story and format to a bunch of testosterone charged heterosexual teenagers.This is nothing more than a psychological teenage sexual indulgence with which Freud and Jung would have had a field day! A female (had to happen!) terminator who uses her breasts as means of distracting a policeman; talk of making out in the basement when they were (wait for it . . .) *teenagers* and apparently having made a good impression; seductively licking the blood off the victim in the vet's clinic; the right age for breeding . . . . need I go on?? Ugh . . . the American obsession with the boy girl thing in their movies is just so last year and so has been.Boring boring boring beyond belief. No attention or dedication to furthering the story - no, just a 15 minute fantasy thrill while Ms Blonde Hair and Big Knockers wreaks havoc, chaos and destruction on the streets with a vehicle crane.Even Arnie's delectably dry humour fell short as he tried to prop up a cast of amateurs and a weak story line and plot.A complete disaster.

Review title: Someone pointed the camera at the wrong place, at the wrong time.
Review_body: Dear god, this film is just beyond word. It has no need to have ever been made after terminator 2, which was good. The way they explain why the war wasn't stopped... really wasn't an explanation at all "judgement day is inevitable". Well, how scientific, i didn't know Jonathan Mostow put so much thought in to it there. Arnold acting in this is worse then usual, like you ever thought that possible. The CGI is credible, but not nearly enough to save this doomed film. After terminator 2, the story ended with a sense of ambiguity, almost to give the film a more realistic edge, what the screen doesn't show me, my mind makes it more powerful by imagining the outcome. The creation of this movie has ruined this mental picture, and ruined the last shred of Arnold Schwarzeneggers dignity. At least in the other films he was cool and hard, they ruined it by adding the comedy aspect (you all know what i'm talking about). Why did James Cameron let this complete idiot tamper with his finished project? There was no need for a third film, let it go. Do not see this film!!!

... in the very sense of the word. Some jokes like "talk to the hand" are hilarious but the whole movie holds on to an aging Terminator, odd!Technically the film is great and the special effects are very good as well and to be honest, Kristina Lokken is easier on the eye than Arnie or the T-1000, but overall the film is weak and that is mainly due to the story itself. After the very successful sequel from 1991 all had been said, the world had been saved and this could have been a prime example of how not to spoil a good idea to bring the Terminator back once.Anyway, the damage is done!

Well, saw it last night at my local megaplex and I must say, well worth the wait, and it was perhaps even better than T2.  This movie is one George Lucas needs to take some lessons from, there are LOTS of special effects in this movie but none of them detract from the movie, and none of them look obviously computer generated (such as 80% of SW I & II).This was one of those rare movies where the whole theater erupted in spontaneous cheers and laughter in a whole multitude of scenes which made the experience even more pleasurable.  Not to mention all the happy faces coming out of the theater on the way out, so I'm reasonably sure I'm not alone in my assessment that this is an awesome movie.Good story line, no "give me a break!", "that's lame", "as if anyone would do that" kind of scenes.  No 5 minute love story nonsense; this movie means to be an action movie and doesn't disappoint.  Humor thrown in at almost exactly the right points, as to not let things get too gloomy, and Arnold delivers the lines perfectly.Rating: 9/10

While the effects might seem a bit rushed the entire film rocks and rolls though some familiar Terminator territory.  The film thankfully ends on time, any more would have been flogging.The scary thing is when it dawns on you that Arnold, without much formal education but with the smarts to learn a lot of lines, wants to govern the people of California.If it happens lets get SkyNet up and running FAST!

Let's cut to the chase, Terminator 3 is massively inferior to the two previous films.  And with a such a solid setup in place, Jonathan Mostow really must hold his hands up.  The problem here is the script, script, script.  I sat disbelieving as gag after gag rolled.  All very well, but this is a Terminator film, and regardless of the director's vision you have to respect what the previous films have set out, and by making the third film a comedy action flick, you're going to annoy a lot of fans 10 minutes in.  The third film has SO much scope - computers taking over the world killing billions of people in the process - yet after 109 minutes, you feel like not much has happened at all.  And that is unforgivable.  Arnie's Terminator is much less likeable, and has little chemistry with John Connor (the script doesn't allow much interaction).  It is a real pity Edward Furlong couldn't do this film, because he really had that strong personality coupled with vulnerability that made the Connor character his own.  Nick Stahl, as good an actor as he is, is just too wimpy and unassuming. The TX is a nice touch, but Robert Patrick's Terminator felt much more deadly.  But I guess that's the problem here: it just doesn't feel thoughtout at all - we need a decent plot to get back into feeling for Arnie and John Connor.  We need more than action sequences to fully feel what Judgement Day will look like.  Especially T2 did this - Cameron's film was brilliantly structured, and so simply scary.  You could feel the clock ticking towards armageddon.  So much happened in that film, by the end of it you felt like you were losing a friend when Arnie died, in this film you really feel little attachment to any of the characters.Overall, a disappointment.  This could, and should, have been a great finale, yet little in the way of intelligent plotting or characterisation leaves you with a cold feeling by the end.  I wanted to like this film, but Jonathan Mostow is getting into a habit of shooting slick films with potholed scripts.  Frustrating!

Review title: Pretty good action movie but mediocre Terminator film
Review_body: While T3 does have some good ideas on the Terminator storyline it falls way short of the greatness of the first two.  Instead of introducing exciting original action sequences we get thinly disguised remakes of chases and scenes from mostly T2.  Instead of an original villain we get the female version of Robert Patrick's T-1000.  Instead of a strong complex female lead we have a frightened Clara Danes.  It's not all disappointing though. The conclusion is haunting and quite eerie.  I just wish the rest of the movie had that kind of emotional impact.

Review title: Thrill ride that should have been longer...
Review_body: Entertaining road movie that is, sadly, not as ambitious as the first two Terminator movies. Could have done with at least 10 extra minutes of character development, which would have added to the impact of several clever plot twists.Unfortunately, the vulnerability of Edward Furlong would have been better suited to the role of John Connor in this flick than the "action figure/pretty boy" features of Nick Stahl. Nevertheless, Claire Danes is more than effective in her role, and Arnie's Terminator remains an iconic figure.The crane chase may be the second best stunt of the summer, behind the Matrix Reloaded's freeway scenes.

This series follows the path of Jaws.First was very good, second very good and the next are comedies and such a crap.Part 3 is alike second but worse. Hope this will be forgotten and somebody someday makes it again.If directors suppose we like those empty chasing, sex and explosions they are going to loose the game. Ok, maybe this is what they expect in US.

I was going into this movie thinking that it was a generic money machine (so i thought from hearing all the reviews).  It turned out that i was pleasantly surprised by a well written and action packed movie!  It tied in perfectly with the past terminators and i was not dissappointed at all.  I thought the absence of Sarah Conner would be dissappointing, but after seeing the movie i was not.  To me its the surprise movie of the summer. Will watch this one again! Cant wait until the trilogy comes out on DVD!!

Review title: Simply Awesome. Terminator/Arnie fans, DON'T MISS IT!
Review_body: The movie was really great and Arnie looked fantastic as always. Kristanna Loken was gorgeous and downright evil as a female terminator. This was the best movie I've seen this year by far. I can't wait until Terminator 4 comes out to finish out the series."Super" Dave

I personally liked this movie a lot. The chase scene leaves everything behind in the dust, including The French Connection. SFX are good and not over the top like other movies. I never thought Hollywood would ever come up with such a good ending, other directors should take great notice of this and learn. The cast is very good and the focus of the film is on John Connor and not on his mom like the two first ones were (T2 to a lesser extent) and it is truly a new chapter in the series. Furlong is not missed. Kristanna is doing a great job, she ain't something you wanna' play with :-D Clair and Nick are truly actors of high caliber and the bottom line is that Arnold is VERY good. The blend with occasional light hearted dialog in a very somber movie is great, it would have been too heavy otherwise.I WANT MORE!

Review title: first good action movie in years
Review_body: It's entertaining, it doesn't drag, it lacks cliches, the script is clever and witty, the acting is good, the characters' actions are plausible, the ending is original, and overall the movie is better than the previous two Terminators. Wow! Just when Matrix Reloaded had made me completely lose faith in the sci-fi / action movie genre, T3 comes as a refreshing, pleasant surprise.

T3 is more of an attempt to simply do a sequel for money. The plot line is fairly convoluted and seems more like the second part in a trilogy.Arnold is simply Arnold. He is okay, the action is as expected, lines seems more forced and the writing is not as witty as T2. Nick Stahl seems more like a TV actor and doesn't have the anger that Eddie Furlong portrayed in T2. Claire Danes does a decent job as his future spouse. Kristanna Loken as T-X is a little confusing as a character and a Terminator. Is she an improvement? She has more mechanical breakdowns than the T-1000 series. She is a babe. She tries to be icy like Robert Patrick did in T2, but to me she needs more training.My major beef about the movie is some obvious script flaws. Claire's father is in charge of an secret Air Force research lab and she along with John Conner and Arnold manage to simply waltz into this facility without even a glitch, loaded with weapons and explosives. Good security, especially in the times we live in now.The other downer is the end. How can the future be written in stone. I find this extremely unbelievable that not one thing all these people do, doesn't appear to change one thing in the future time line.
I wish James Cameron was involved with this project. He is a much better writer/director for this type of genre.

This was the best action movie I have ever seen.  Arnold's back in the role he was born to play and he's taking us on a non-stop ride packed with action, adventure, and few good laughs.  This movie combines the darkness of the first film with the blockbuster action of the second film (without the cheese) and delivers up The Perfect Terminator movie.  After the film was over I immediately wanted  to see it again.  Very rarely does a movie leave you feeling this excited after you've viewed it.  I hope they make a 4th installment, but if they don't this will be an excellent way to go out.  I give this movie 5 stars out of 4!--=Evil Ed=--

Review title: A great addition to the Terminator series, but it's no T2
Review_body: Just don't expect something to top Terminator 2 when you sit down and watch it.  I can't say that enough.However, the movie is definitely exciting and very good...finally a good movie in the summer of 2003.  Incredible action sequences (the car chase is better than the Matrix's) and a great story with some interesting characters.  The TX terminator does a really good job (almost as good as Robert Patrick did in T2) and is also extremely hot.  So, yeah, nothing wrong there.Go check it out, especially if you loved T2.  This is definitely a movie to catch this summer no matter what, though.

I have just experienced the best action scenes I have ever seen. The story is perfect and exceeded by far my expectations.Note: If you have not seen T1 & T2 you will be lost. And if you have, you are going to love this one. Have not seen T3 yet ? What are you waiting for ?

Review title: good flick, better than I expected
Review_body: I was a big fan of T1 and even a bigger fan of T2.  I have to admit, I expected nothing from T3 at all; I was afraid of them ruining it.After all was said and done, it was way better than I expected.  Although it had a few technical problems here and there, over all it was a good movie with a non-hollywood ending.  Give it a try!

Review title: Who said this guy could direct?
Review_body: Why did this director take all of the things that had been done in the first 2 movies and try to put them into this movie?  I'll tell you why, because he didn't have a CLUE as to how to direct.  Arnold is really stretching now for a hit and this is just not it.  It was more like a video game than a movie. All of the scenes at the middle and end of the movie looked JUST like a video game first person shooter.  Long hallways that go on for ever for no real purpose, and action that was there just for the sake of action, what happened to a plot?

The beginning of the third Terminator was too noisy, too destructive... then the pieces of the puzzle came together and everything just made perfect sense. The end of this Terminator 3 makes you dream about what Terminator 4: Post-Judgment Day could be!

Review title: Frailty, Thy Name is Woman? I Think Not!
Review_body: Of Course! What is more vicious and determined than a woman who knows what she is after. Saw advanced screening last night (7/1). Plenty of destruction without the visible gore of the first two. Here it is more implied. A splash of blood on a picture, a couple of bullet holes on a body and a LOT of gunfire amidst chaos. On the whole, it is just shy of T2 only because of the parallel to it and the lack of Linda Hamilton. A couple of nice little twists including the end. Enjoy!

I say this while also believing james cameron is one of the best directors in history (he's my favorite for sure).  the acting is great, the cinimetography is great, and yes, the directing is great.  i don't really know much of mostow's work besides Breakdown, but this was awesome.  i was scared 3 years ago that they were going to have someone like john woo or McG direct it (thank god).
the story...well the story is deep...the apocalypticism is what i love the most about T1 and T2.  And in T3, it is awesome.  so take it from me, i'm a huge cameron fan, i even liked titanic.  this movie is amazing and i am glad they made it.

Review title: Not a quality movie, just another shoot 'em up
Review_body: I don't know how Terminator 3 got a 6.8 in the voting because it deserves no more than a 4. This movie is just another Arnold shoot 'em up. Now don't get me wrong, I love Arnold. But this movie was really bad. It just got worse as it went. The ending was the worst. It was really stupid. Once in a while, an Arnold movie can be good, but this movie is not a 6.8. I would not recommend anyone from renting, buying or seeing this movie unless your IQ is under 65 or you are nine years old. This was not one of Arnold's finer moments in film. The best of the Terminator series was Terminator 2 which is strange because usually the first movie in a series is the best. The basic plot for this movie was: a guy in the future will lead the humans to victory against the robots; the robots of the future send a robot into the past to try and kill the guy and Arnold (a robot for the humans) has to try to protect the guy from that robot.

If i didn't know that a different director filmed this movie as opposed to James Cameron, I never would have been able to tell the difference.  I really enjoy the first two, but this one just takes the cake.  I was so impressed with the special effects and the acting.  Everyone did a great job.  And the end gave me goose bumps.  Three cheers to Jonathan Mostow!

there was so little expectation for this film and a lot of negative press, all they kept saying was that this was an unneccesary sequel but you know what? these are the same idiots that praise charlies angels 2 and legally blonde 2---THIS MOVIE WAS GOOD AND IT WAS MORE THAN JUST AN ALL OUT ACTION THRILLER!
It basically explained the whole concept of fate and nicely tied itself to the first 2 movies of the terminator series.  I loved it and I can't wait til this comes out on DVD-- Although there might not be a Terminator 4, this movie was so dramatic and riviting that it makes you want to see another Terminator movie!Two thumbs up...

As I think T3 it is nothing without James Cameron.  This movie it's only an interminable series of persecutions without sense.  When we will really see the war of the machines against the man?  On the other hand any comparison with The Matrix is abominable.  Please Cameron, come and saves the series. Regards.

7.3/10 right now and you IMDB people post a mostly negative review? This movie is very good, as good as the first two but different and darker.  I don't know why some people think that every movie must have Shakespearean verse to be good.  This is a terminator movie.  Lighten up people.  I love that this movie doesn't take itself too seriously.  This one definitely has the most humor and the action is on par with the other films.  I LOVED that T3 had a dark side to it as well.If you liked/loved the first 2 terminator movies, you will like/love this one.  If you didn't like/love the first 2 terminator movies then why even bother seeing this one and panning it?

Review title: A great follow up to the Terminator series
Review_body: I have been waiting for this movie ever since I first saw T2 many years ago. Now that I have seen it, I can positively say that this was a really good movie and would even enjoyable to the audience that hasn't been longing for this movie as I have. Although this movie was a bit more comical then the previous movies and there is a noticeable difference between this movie and the others because of the absence of James Cameron, it still holds that true Terminator feeling. My only problem with this movie would be the length, barely and hour and a half, which is an half an hour shorter than the spectacular T2. I do suggest this to any terminator or non-terminator fan, you don't need to know every thing about the story to keep you into like some new movies out right now.

Review title: Good action, but found the story lacking
Review_body: Great stunts through out the movie, but even though there was lots of action I didn't like how the movie went a little cheesy.  "Talk to the hand", was funny, but didn't belong.   And the ending was terrible.  I guess they will look at making number 4 so we will finally see the battle of man versus machine in the future.

There's action all the movie. There are so much bullets and car crash that i do know now why it have cost this much. Anyway, if you want to see a really good movie of action ( a lot of action) this is the number one!!! And finally a end that satisfied me!

*Spoliers* I just got back from seeing T3 tonight.  At first I was not sure whether I really loved it or I really hated it.   I have since decided on the former.  I went into the movie with a very hopeful yet skeptical attitude.  Ok, the movie.  At first I was afraid that my fears were coming true (the stupid sunglasses, talk to the hand - which actually was incredibly funny to me). The T-X made me quite sketical at first because she is so hot that I could not think of her being a mean ass. Then when she connects to the net through her phone I thought "oh d*mn." From then on out she is a bad*ss.  The chase through LA is hands down awesome.  Much better than the Matrix Reloaded chase (though not as long).  The Terminator is very good.  If a little more emotive than he should be.  Things about the movie that I really loved: Skynet coming online was so cool. There really wasnt much to it, but just knowing that it was happening was so cool. Conner realizing that judgement day cannot be averted was very good.  I also liked how the machines came to realize that just as judgement day itself could not be avoided, neither could John Conner, so instead they aim at the less important parts in an attempt to lessen the sum - the future generals that serve under Conner. At first I did not like how the movie ended, with the bombs dropping right at the end.  But in retrospect I think it was good that way.  However, it also necessitates another sequel.  I was sorta hoping for some closure.  But I was also itching to see everything blow up. Which also did not really happen.  But I guess that really was not all that necessary. There were a few other bad things.  First of all, there was just a little too much corny humor. Some would have been good, but not as much as was in there.  The sarah conner part was rather lame, in my opinion.  I wish they would have explained some more how the main players all happened to find there way together at the kennel.  The movie sorta throws out the whole "no fate but what we make" thing.  However, I think that is a good thing though. Lastly, I was hoping that Mostow would throw in something about Uncle Bobs left over arm at the end of T2.  All that being said, I am very pleased with this movie. 9 out of 10.

Review title: Great, great summer action flick! Seriously!
Review_body: I am a big independent film fan and love great scripts and great acting...so this opinion, I believe is coming from a credible place.This movie was a lot of fun!  Definitely delivered the action, the witty comments and Arn-old was great!  It's possibly the loudest movie I've ever seen and there is a good amount of action!Look, if you come into this movie expecting an amazing script and Oscar-calibur performances, wait until November!  This is a July 4th weekend, which means fun, no brain, blow-em-up action flick time!  It's not too long, not too short, not too slow, mostly good dialogued film!  Much, much better than The Hulk!  The action is believable (assuming you've seen T2) and the effects are dazzling!I came into this film today expecting it to be really bad with a new John Conner, a new director, a new vision and an aging Ar-nold!  But I was pleasently suprised at what I saw!  Watch Terminator or more importantly T2 (since it seems that most of this Terminator drew from the T2 storyline). Sit back with a big bucket of popcorn and soda and forget your life for two hours.  Enjoy it, it was fun and really entertaining if not a bit thought-provoking!I gave it an 8.  In reality, I would give it a perfect 7, but since so many people thought it sucked (since they expected it to be as good as T2), I had to overrate it by 1 star!

Though some fans did not like T3, I found it enjoyable, entertaining and not as insulting to the original films as some movie watchers seemed to find it. T3 had its definite cheesy moments (but so did the first two T-movies if one recalls! - T1 and T2 had some of the worst dialogue audiences should ever be forced to sit through - a Cameron trademark.)Though T3 contradicted some of the theories established in the first two films, all in all the contradictions were explained and they worked...This was a roller-coaster ride of a film and a lot of fun -- not as "unintelligent" as some reviewers would like readers to believe.

Is this film as good as T1 and T2?  No.  Is this film a decent addition to the family?  Absolutley!Since this was just released, I'm going to do my best to write a review without giving much of the plot away.On the surface, there's not much new here from T2.  Arnold is back to defend John Connor from a shape-shifting terminator.  This one's tougher and sexier than Rober Patrick, but that has nothing to do with this positive review... :)First and foremost, I liked how they continued the story.  After T2, I wasn't sure how they could extend the existing plotline while remaining believable.  I love the set-up for Connor, the new mission for both terminators, the twists along the way, and the revelation at the end.Furthermore, I was impressed with what Nick Stahl did with the part of Connor.  He had some pretty cliche lines to deliver from time to time, but his portrayal made me care about him.Jonathon Mostow has a great eye for action sequences, and has done an admirable job at the very unenviable task of following up a James Cameron classic.

This is one awesome movie. You get an 5 min. introduction to where we are, who's in it and then it all begins. The plot might be a little on the thinner side of what people might expect, but the action, funny antics, that only is possible in the movie because of what became cool in it's preceding movies. The whole strip club scene is hilarious. The new way they use the fact that Arnold is playing a robot also makes for some funny scenes. Then there is the fight scenes and the spectacular car chase. well just mind blowing action made Matrix style... you'll remember it even if you dont want to.This movie is nothing like T1 or T2 and it dose not really matter. T1&T2 is history and they made this third chapter in such a manner that it dose not ruin anything of the past two. You can watch the first 2 and complete ignore the third because it begins a new story line of it's own. You can even watch the third movie without knowing much of the former two.
The plot, characters etc may be in the low end of the scale... But dang it was entertaining to watch.. twice :Dblah blah bad English etc my opinion... :]

T3 was a decent film despite the fact that I entered the theater with the false pretense that Mostow would be able to imitate Cameron's style in T1 and T2.  The only reason I could see the need to have a Terminatrix was for the sex appeal.  Had Robert Patrick (T- 1000) been brought back, the film would've been equally good, if not better. There were definitely some moments where Ahnold's one-liners were just hilarious. I would've liked to have seen a slightly stronger ending.  You'll never forget Sarah Connor driving off into the desert, or Ahnold sticking up his thumb as he's getting submerged in the hot steal.  But nukes being launched everywhere?Not sure if this will conclude the Terminator legacy, but if they do make another one, I'll definitely go see it.

Review title: Good, but shows how amazing terminator 2 is
Review_body: I saw Terminator 3 tonight and I msut say that it was good.  I was somewhat dissapointed by it since T2 set such high standards, but it was nonetheless a very solid movie.  T2 was made in 1991 with a budget of 100 million.  To me this movie still holds its ground to T3, a movie made 12 years later. Cameron's presence was missed on this film, but Mostow did a job well done and can hopefully spawn a sequel of two off this story line.  Although not as good as T2 it keeps the franchise alive and the story provides more than enough interest for another movie.8/10

Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is, quite frankly, a failure.Let us start with the inferior special effects: Given that the film cost 187 million dollars to make, one would expect superior quality special effects, or, at least, high quality. However, it was not delivered.A terminator exists for one purpose: to kill. It is relentless, brutal, and every feature of its design is meant to facilitate more efficient killing. As a special effects artist, one should create imagery that captures this idea... So.. my question is... how exactly will those glowing lights help a terminator kill??? both terminators have an EXCESSIVE amount of glowing, Christmas-tree like features. the T-101 has red and green lights inside its chest, and the T-X is practically a walking blue LED. It reminds one of geeky PC with UV lights rather than a killing machine.we will also note that the T-X comes with tiny a rotary saw!! i mean, come on!! the giant stabbing sword of t-1000 provided a much better visual representation of brutality. Big, sharp, pointy objects looks menacing, blurry round things doesn't, especially when it's about 2 inches in diameter and comes with the sound FX of a dentist's drill.the physics is horrible as well, in the hand-to-hand combat scene, the T-X manage to throw T-101 for 10 meters without moving back an inch. And no, it doesn't make T-X look strong, it makes the entire scene look artificial, like a bad kung-fu movie. There is also a scene where the T-101 pulls open the door of a safe: not only is that physically impossible (if it were a real safe one most most likely pull the entire safe out of the wall) but the scene also fails to convey the message that the terminator is strong. To covey strength visually, one need to establish visually that 1) something is difficult to do and 2) the character does this difficult thing, so he/she is strong. Throughout the film the terminators perform feats of strength way too effortlessly, which takes away the realism. (in comparison, Robert Patrick's hand to hand fight scene in T2 was much much better.There are two more scenes that bugs me visually. One is the scene where T-X sends electric signals to police cars. the computer generated graphics looks like something from the 1980's. the other scene is where cathrine bruster shot T-101 and T-101 spits out the bullet. If i had designed that scene i would have had the bullet tear off a large chunk of T-101's cheek, making a wound that looks like a menacing grin while revealing its metal mandible, or better yet, tear off a piece of T-101's eye.. or, at the very least, show some blood... but nooo.. the T-101, simply catches the bullet with its mouth.. like.. some parlor trick... sigh..Aside from the special effects problem, there are script problem as well.. ill place humor is a huge problem in this movie.T-101 saying "talk to the hand" is just not funny.T-101 wearing star shaped sun-glasses.. not funny either...T-101 saying "excuse me" to T-X: not funny.cathrine bruster punching T-101 in back the same way that most girls punch guys when they are flirting with them: what is this: a romantic comedy? T-X saying "i like your car" "i like your gun"... just plain weird.T-X breast enlargement: serves no purpose. (she was gonna kill the cop anyway, not like there is a NEED for deception and doing things for no apparent purpose destroy the whole image of the Sparthan, cold blooded killing machine.) T-X always walking like she was on a catwalk.. neither funny, nor sexy, nor cool, nor menacing.T-X having a strange curious look before using her remote control ability: just plain weird to see cold blooded killing machine with the look of curiosity! In short.. the film sucks...

Review title: No fate but what we make or inevitability?
Review_body: I've loved the first two (especially the second) Terminator movies ever since I can remember.  I was only six years old when I saw the first one. This was because my parents left us with a babysitter who was not supposed to show us the film, but did anyway.  If I still knew who that man was I would thank him today because at age six I was scared of the Terminator but loved Arnold Schwarzenegger.  He is still my favorite actor today.In the first two, the story is very similar, but the second movie gets deeper in thought.  The quote, "There is no fate but what we make for ourselves" was a theme, so to speak, and it worked well.  The machines sent a Terminator through time to change what the future had brought. Apparently John Connor is supposed to be the leader of the human race, and the machines feel he is going to be there demise.  Since he is such a powerful leader in the future, they feel it be best to go back in time to destroy him before he becomes such an influential and strong man.  In each movie the Terminator fails, but the machines appear to become more advanced (since model 101 was replaced with 1000 from the first to the second).  At the end of T2, we get the idea that it must be the end, and Judgment Day was no longer in the world's future.Enter Terminator 3.  The "theme" in this movie is almost a contradiction to T2's theme.  (semi-spoiler)  The Terminator explains to John that Judgment Day is inevitable, and that John's fate is to become the leader of the human race.  Therefore no matter what they do Judgment Day is still going to happen.  The one thing that confused me was the fact that there was still a Terminator sent back to try and destroy John Connor.  If the future is inevitable, then why send a machine back when they know it's not going to work?  Maybe the idea that the future happens only one way is not true, but rather just a speculation.  Whatever the outcome may be, the machines do realize the importance of John Connor and will try almost anything to terminate him.The end of the movie was great, and I was quite amazed and shocked at it. I wasn't expecting it at all, but loved it just the same.  The movie is also great because it lives up to the Terminator name.  The special effects are mind-blowing and the scenes are intense.  If you liked T2, you should definitely not wait to see this one.  Besides, you want to see the fourth one as well, don't you?  You decide, is it fate or inevitability that Terminator 4 will be in our future?

Review title: The T-1000 would Destroy the T-X
Review_body: first of all im a die hard terminator fan i have been since i saw T-2 when i was 5 i saw T3 in theaters i thought it was OK i was expecting something a little better but anyways what i don't get is why they would send something less advanced than the t-1000 the T-x is cool (and hot) don't get me wrong but the thing is an anti-terminator and if she would try to attempt to terminate the t-1000 she would fail because she would shoot him with that ray gun she has and it would go through him and the t-1000 would basically do what he did to the T-800 (arnie) in the end of T2 which is completely F@#K him up so yeah thats what i really didn't like about that movie does anyone else agree?

Review title: Shocked by how much I enjoyed this.
Review_body: As has been said time and time again, I went in with a low expectation, and came out blown away by how good of an action film this was. I could go into a detailed commentary on the film, but instead I think I'll just make a few points. The comedy was definately over the top at times.  Frankly I loved it. Some have critiqued the TX's design as being more primitive than that of the T1000.  These people may be forgetting the T1000's drawback.  The T1000 can not transform itself into a weapon.  It can't form projectile weapons out of itself.  By combining the liquid metal with an android skeleton, we come up with an interesting mix.  It can repair itself in the manner of the T1000, albeit it with some limitations.  However, it gains the ability to create weapons out of itself.  That arm cannon was absurdly powerful.  The flamethrower was a tad weak I'll admit, but that was a secondary attack. Something I want to note that I don't think many people pick up on in T2. When Arnold is lowered into the molten steel, the chip and arm from the first movie were destroyed.  Interestingly though, when Arnold was lowered, he had one arm.  The other arm was ripped off by a gear.  That arm was left behind, in the gear.  This is just a theory of mine, but I always wondered what happened to that arm.  Interestingly, on the general's desk we find a metal Terminator hand.  Could there be a connection here? I did want to briefly comment on the death of Sara Connor's dream that the future is something we can create out of free willed choice, and not deterministic.  It's sad to think that everything is predestined to happen in a certain way.  I hope in the next installment of this franchise, which now seems to be a certainty, that they find a way to return free will to the story. The idea of Skynet being software as opposed to some sort of mainframe was very intriguing.  It makes the reference to Pandora's Box by the general much more compelling.  There was literally no way to put Skynet back in the box after it was unleashed.  There are several versions of the Pandora's Box myth.  In one version, only one virtue is left within the box, without which humanity would surely have been crushed by all the evils it had unleashed. Hope.  Hope here is personified in the form of John Connor and Kate Brewster. I'd give this film.. oh.. 4.5/5.

Review title: Really is the best of 2003 summer season
Review_body: Best of the series, flushes out the story and fills in the holes, that we all had figured out.  Funny chase scenes, great effects, just a D&*( good movie, break from reality and a great way to spend a couple of hours. Waiting on Terminator 4 now when I had my doubts after 2.

Wow, just got back from Arnold's new flick, or perhaps it's not only Arnold's: wonderful to see him finally again sharing the screen with other actors. The film truly delivered, it was action packed, yet, unlike the matrix, the action was remarkably realistic (as realistic as you can go with robots from the future). Arnie was in his old form: fewer lines, more punching, and yes he was funny... Almost all of his one-liners worked with the crowed, and yap, a number of times the theater burst out laughing. The plot was strong, and while it wasn't adventurous by having too many side plots, it delivered, and stayed strong through out the movie.Performances were excellent: John Connor (Nick Stahl) was strong and convincing, Arnie was Arnie , and TX (Kristanna Loken) was hot yet managed to stay scary... The only major actor who I was not really positive about was Kate Brewster (Claire Danes) they tried to replace John's mom with a new face, but I think they should have dropped that personality from the story...Special FX were well done, but not over done... They left off from the old T2, and managed to have the same combination of CGI effects and real effect (i.e. explosions) in a very convincing fashion, quiet amazing... However, while T2's effects were groundbreaking, T3's were just plain excellent...Finally the ending sequence and the twist, were unexpected and positive, and in my honest opinion left the crowed very happy.The movie wasn't as smooth as T2, and probably could best be compared to ease of transition to The Transporter and Bourn Identity, the best recent action films I could think of.Overall the film was a surprise, I expected eye candy, and I certainly got it, but the strong preferences and compelling plot elevated it to the top action film in recent memory. So anyone who can enjoy an action film should see this one!8.5/10

Sure, Terminatrix is Hot, but it is not utilized in any manner Sure sure, the action parts are ok, but nothing new or exceptional - I mean a car chasing scene using heavy vehicles has been seen before (where was it now - oh that's right in T2) No new cool gimmicks or robot-abilities - reuse of the melting robot adding weaponry does not make it up for something new - Terminatrix is more of a T2 meets Robocop. The cast is playing like wet cardboard in a recycling dumpster The lines must have been picked up in a box labelled "Corny" - "My Fathers plane - I have been training in that"... Though Arnold's referring to some of his older lines are funny, but...

Quick and too the point. Lots of action, some laughs too. The doctor from the second movie is back. Of course the terminators just get nastier every time, and much better looking.Great ending, and you got to love the T-2! What more could you ask for?

I was of the school of thought that this film was going to be terrible. Arnie was too old; Jim Cameron wasn't on board; Nick Stahl was in Disturbing Behaviour! These are the sorts of things an ordinary movie could not get over.T3 is not ordinary.The action sequences are spectacular, even more so because they are (take note Wachowski's and Lucas) REAL! Obviously some CG effects were used but it wasn't entirely CG (which might have worked for Neo) and that in itself was a treat.The director builds a real sense of pressure and a real sense of style right up until the decidedly non-Hollywood ending, which even its predecessor did, the direction is just on the right side of post-modern irony and the performances (bar one) are great.This leads us nicely onto the big man himself... Mr. (Governor?) Schwarzenegger is now 56 years old, he first played the T-100 in 1984 and he has progressed through the years into a different actor to when he started.  All in all a tough assignment! He manages to just make us believe he is the T-100 again, it's amazing.  I forgot he was Arnie; all I knew was that if he wanted to he could have snapped John Connor's neck like a twig (good thing if Edward Furlong was involved).Just for fairness though I must point out what I thought the weak link was Kristanna Loken, now before anyone starts I have nothing against models-turned-actors but in this case Miss Loken should have kept her mouth shut and her legs waxed.  She is just not Robert Patrick, she doesn't ever have the sense of malice that he managed to put into the T-1000 and for that she fails.Anyways that's my quick review; I do recommend you go see the film when it comes out over here you really won't be disappointed

Review title: Falls short of T1, way short of T2
Review_body: I went into this movie hoping to be surprised if not downright delighted at what I was seeing.  I had hoped that it wouldn't be just another Hollywood big budget sequel that falls short of anything above average.  I was, however, very disappointed with what I saw.  It was just another Hollywood sequel that had little to add to the first two movies.I was not, however, totally put off by the film.  There were some excellent sequences that deserve the proper recognition.  The crane chase was creative and entertaining.  A few other ideas that I won't mention were good, along with the introduction to skynet, but these were not enough.  I didn't feel the same intensity that T2 brought me, or the sense of originality that T1 gave to me.The movie runs short, less than two hours.  The dialogue seemed a little cheap.  But worst of all, the story was second rate.  For as much money as they spent, they could make sure everything is excellent, not just the special effects.  If you want nonstop action, by all means see this movie. If you want a thought provoking epic, look elsewhere. 6/10

It was pretty good.  Some will fault T3 because of the lacking of some characters, but it does not hurt this film.  It has more plot than T1, or T2 combined.The lack of Cameron does not bother me at all.  It also has several twists that give it more depth than the previous Terminator movies.  The special effects were great, well above the Matrix movies if you ask me.  CGI use was nice and not overdone.Arnold is back in top shape for this one as well.  I really hope we see a T4.  I think it was not a good time to release T3.  My theatre was pretty empty on Friday night (the 4th of July).  I think a lot of people were out to other Holiday parties.  I guess we'll know on later on.More action, more destruction, more plot, more Terminator, go see it!

Just got back from seeing Terminator 3 and I have to say this was a fantastic movie.  The chase scenes are spectacular, the CG are awesome and the story is classic.  I am so happy to comeback with this feeling and I am sure that this will be a true summer blockbuster.  Arnold was awesome plain and simple.  He reprises the role so perfect, the one-liners , the robotic movement it was fantastic.  Danes and Stahl have great chemistry and the T-X was a nice change.  Cant wait till T-4, remember " We will meet again"

First off I must confess that I'm not a member of the church of Terminator. I was 5 years old when T2 came out and I missed out on all the hype and excitement surrounding its release. The first time I saw T2 was right before watching T3; I had seen the first movie before. On DVD and 12 years separated from the hype, T2 is a decent action movie but nothing more; I found James Cameron's attempts at creating human drama to be just as laughable as they were in Titanic. Because I wasn't really anticipating this movie, it wasn't a big deal to me when it turned out to be a dud (especially considering I got in free thanks to an employee friend's passes). If you are a fanboy, brace yourself; I haven't seen anything quite so hilarious and sad for quite some time as the shell-shocked, horrified look on the face of a man in the row behind me at the end of the movie; as everyone filed out, he stayed glued to his seat, his mouth slightly open, staring transfixed at the screen like it was some horrible train-wreck. I have a creeping suspicion he was praying for Ashton Kutcher to appear and scream "YOU'VE BEEN PUNK'D BY THE PUNKERS ON MTV'S PUNK'D, PUNK!"Before 1999, action movies were about big, brutal fights and explosions. On March 31, 1999, The Matrix slipped quietly into theaters and we all know what happened next. For better or for worse, T3 is a throwback film of sorts. There is, as in Matrix Reloaded, one huge car-chase set piece; it plays out more like director Jonathan Mostow challenging himself to see how much of the ridiculous $170 million budget he can spend blowing things up and knocking things over in a couple minutes, all while shaking the camera around and cutting quickly enough that you have only a faint inkling of what's going on. All the movie's action sequences play out like this; yes, the explosions are big, but none of it is terribly interesting or creative.I'm not going to bother with the plot, which serves as a vehicle for 1) the effects and 2) the setup for a couple more of these movies than a story in its own right.
