What some will inevitably call a daring and imaginate shakeup of the Terminator mythos is more a necessarily overcomplex way to milk an artificial conflict out of a storyline that was concluded 12 years ago.This is a franchise exercise and a calculated move, not a film. If that doesn't dissuade you from seeing it, since 90% of Hollywood's movies are that way, hopefully the fact that it's a bad one will.

I must say, I was a bit skeptical when I heard that this movie was coming out.  I had a feeling that Hollywood was trying to milk an old, tired cash cow, but boy was I wrong.  It's not quite as good as T2, but not much is. The Terminator story continues on as the machines begin their rise to power. This flick is full of action, including one chase scene that rivals the now legendary chase in The Matrix Reloaded, ridiculous gun shoot outs and brief comedic moments that Terminator fans are used to.  Arnold gives a great performance as the T-101 again and the new "Terminatrix" chick is unbelievably hot, even though the nude appearance scene was a little too "PG-13" for me.  I definitely recommend checking this out.$$$ 1/4 (out of $$$$)

I was quite impressed with the plot line of this film and would reccomend that anyone who is a fan of the series go to see it.  If the fourth is produced this sets it up well.  There were some things in the movie that were there for cheap laughs, but they are tolerable if you like the plot.

Review title: When movies stop being about art, and start being about money.
Review_body: ***This comment is one gigantic spoiler, so brace yourself*** Firstoff I've been a huge Terminator fan since I was the age of 6. I love both films and they're in my Top 3 of movies of all time (Along with The Godfather, and Goodfellas) Now this T3 comes along, and it's supposed to be a bigger more Badass Terminator than we already know. Rather than give my review, I'm going to give you a play-by-play of how this movie starts from my point of view.This movie starts off, no Terminator Theme, no frightening yet mysterious visions of fire, just a black screen with the casts names up there. After a minute of agonizing nothingness, we hear John Connor speak. Now this isn't the rebellious, "Doesn't give a damn," "Leader of the Resistance" John Connor we know and love. No-no-no that would be too cool. Instead he hear the first words of what would later be found to be a whiny little brat that could couldn't lead a dog to a can of Alpo. His first words are "No Fate but what we make for ourselves" (an idea that was presented to us in the first 2 films, but after getting into this 'film', we'll soon realize that James Cameron's idea will be sh-t all over, and it's ass will be wiped with dollar bills.) After we hear him yap for a while, we cut to a CGI nightmare of the future. This scene is the first major rip-off of the first 2 films, the difference is the original version (again, I remind you that it was made in 1984) looked 10x better.Fast forward a few minutes (I mean this movie has to get better,) And we see the classic scene where The Terminator arrives. Only this time it looks like a bad comic book. It literally looks like a parody of the originals. And do we get a tough, bad-ass, gives your children nightmares Terminator ? No-no, again, that would be too cool. We get some Victoria Secret model with neat hair, perfect make-up, and motherly eyes. The overdone CGI, which include the manikins melting and a 'cool' grid that surrounds the time portal is just enough to make me sick to my stomach. After she steals a car (it's a Lexus, by the way if you didn't see the 8 foot, million dollar logo) she makes a call on her (Nokia) cellphone and identifies her 8 targets. Blah-blah, runs red light, cop car, Victoria's Secret ad, boobs, likes cops gun.If that weren't enough of a slap in James Cameron's face, this will be. We see Arnold stroll into a Bar, just like in T2. But get this, it's not a Biker-bar this time, it's...he-he...I can't stop laughing while typing this...it's... a male strip club! And they all think Arnold is a male stripper he-he! While "Macho Man" is playing in the background, Arnold spots clothing that fit him...and get this...they're on a Stripper! Who would have guessed!? BRILLIANT writing. After quite possibly the gayest exchange I've ever seen in a movie (and I've seen Brokeback mountain,) I'm wrong yet again. Apparently the writers thought it would be funny if The Terminator, the same guy who mercilessly shot the wrong Sarah Connor in the face, and tried to run the real one down with a Mac truck...wore pink Elton John sunglasses. Why again did Arnold agree to this ? (Oh yea, 30 million big ones) You can literally hear the writers laughing to themselves. Only it's not a normal laugh, it's one of those geeky, nasally, Steve Urkel laughs. Next scene: How did he remember to look in the sun visor for keys when John taught to the other Terminator? I'm not going to even go into this movie any further, because I honestly feel like I'm losing braincells writing a review for it. In summary, this movie is a joke. An unfunny caricature and borderline parody of, arguably, 2 of the greatest films ever produced. Lets see if the Sarah Connor Chronicles, and T4 can clean up the mess that T3 has made for the franchise.One star.

I really liked this movie.  I am a huge fan of the first two movies, and when I heard that Cameron wasn't directing this one, I was skeptical.  I went in thinking it wasn't gonna be any good, but instead was pleasantly surprised.  They did a really good job of sticking to the "Terminator" story line, without making a carbon copy of T2.  The TX was awesome!!!  The best scenes were when she was fighting Arnold.  I would recommend this movie. Also, there is a little bit of a twist to the "judgement day/Skynet" thing, but I think it was still faithful to the overall storyline.  I don't want to give it away, so go check it out!

Review title: There is no fate but what we make for ourselves...
Review_body: T3 was an amazing experience. I saw an advance screening of it tonight. I believe it surpasses it's expectations. Compared to The Terminator and T2, T3 is action-packed to the bone. Props go to the special effects team. I knew the action in the movie would be incredible. What I was concerned about coming into the theater was whether the plot would be strong or weak. After all, in T2, Judgment Day is prevented. Or is it? We learn early on in the movie that it's only delayed. The war with the machines is inevitable. The plot is complex but understandable. It's not like The Matrix Reloaded. Too keep things short and sweet, T3 spells the sad truth about mankind. The ending brings a tear to the eye. It made me think about how fragile life is. "The future is not set. There is no fate but what we make for ourselves." Think about it. Then go see T3.

This 3rd Terminator movie rocks!!!  I went to see this movie really not knowing what to expect, and came out totally amazed. It makes you understand the first 2 movies a lot better, and understand why the machines exist. GO SEE THIS MOVIE NOW!!!! 10/10

I just saw the Matrix Reloaded. It was humorless, pseudo-intellectual, needlessly complicated, and the fight scenes were tensionless and too long. I didn't like it. So it was nice to see T3 was the exact opposite. Though it started out a little slowly, there were plenty of humorous moments, the plot was simple (supposedly there were continuity issues with the other movies, but even though I saw T2 twice, I didn't notice), the actions scenes were well done, and there were even moments of real emotion. As long as you accept T3 for what it is -- an action movie with no depth -- you will thoroughly enjoy it.

(I will try to write this review without giving away any of the plot, which is particularly difficult because the story was very original).Finally, a hollywood movie that didn't show everything in the trailers. This movie looked borderline for me.. but I am a loyal Sci-Fi Guy so I had to see it, and I wasn't disappointed.  The trailers for this film were uniamiously bad, just your typical action/Arnold-with-a-rocketlauncher, unoriginal shoot-em-up.  What this film ended up being was a delight in acting (notably Nick Stahl as John Connor) and Claire Danes(when is she bad), story, and cinematography.The story really moved along, although it was the typical: chase John, John escapes, Re-acquire John, chase John, John escapes.  The movie felt complete in a way in which the previous installments never really did.  I left the movie satisfied, but not in the typical Hollywood fuzzy way, but in a deeper meaningful understanding way... I would like to think I'm not reading too much into ithis film but everyone I was with totally agreed.I would recommend this movie to any Sci-fi/Action movie fans.. and maybe even some Drama lovers who just want a touch more adventure.

Except for a few scenes, where the art direction is not up to the "Terminator series" class,  the movie has excellent entertainment value. The movie has got excellent special effects and minimal chit-chat as in the 2 prequels. The Terminatrix "Kristanna Loken" has done a decent job, but this was clearly the best performance by Arnie after a long time. Nick Stahl and Claire Danes are not very impressive, but we have to keep in mind that all the action is packed in just 1:48 hrs. The movie ends well with all bases covered. All in all, a perfect action movie with more new and funny one-liners!!

i just T3 Yesterday, It opened a day early in Canada. What can i say, it's the best movie i've seen this whole year. The action is non-stop and surprisingly it had a wonderful story. Arnie of course was just simply great as the terminator, althought this time he mad much more humour that the previous terminators. The rest of the cast did their roles accordingly. The highlight of this movie is seeing Arnold back and the dream is just watchin one of the greatest action movie franchises back. I love good action movies, and none is greater than T2, and watching T3 in this day, where they don't make good movies, it was beautiful to see a movie like this. Arnie is the kick of Action and the Terminator is his gateway to pure mayhem. A must see Movie. ****

The reason that the machines still exist is not hacked together like magical fairies or a wizard did it. There are a few good ironic situations,can you say Elton John HA HA. There are a few unanswered questions not anything that would make the movie incomplete but some things that would make it come together better.

Terminator 3 is a prime example of what I'd call underhype/over-rate syndrome.  We all saw the awful trailers, we all heard about the troubled production history, and we all knew that James Cameron & Linda Hamilton wouldn't be involved.  Suffice it to say, no one I knew thought this movie was going to be very good.  I held out hope that I'd see a reasonably entertaining action movie.That's exactly what I saw, . . . barely.  However, I think that the fact that the movie came with such low expectations, has somehow raised a lot of people's opinions of a very mediocre film (73% fresh on Rotten Tomatoes).But enough about other people's opinions, lets get to mine.  I watched Terminator 3 with a smile throughout most of it. It wasn't a big goofy smile, or a wide-eyed look of awe or shock, but a pleasant, mildly amused smile.  I left the theater entertained, but I almost immediately began to forget the movie I just saw.I started to think about why my reaction was so luke warm.  I think I can boil it down to this: There wasn't one moment in the movie that thrilled or surprised me.  For a Sci-Fi action movie, let alone the 3rd installment in a series, that's a fatal flaw in my book.  Where did it go wrong? Here's my breakdown:CHARACTERS: - T101 - Great to see Arnold back as the T-101, I actually liked him better here than I did in T2.  He has a couple of funny lines, but like the rest of the film they are mildly amusing and instantly forgettable. - John Connor - Nick Stahl is less annoying than Edward Furlong but not anymore interesting.  He's actually quite bland and didn't generate empathy for his character. - Kate Brewster - Claire Danes manages to make her more empathetic and engaging than John Connor, but the two characters have zero chemistry together.  Any human drama that might have made the movie more interesting is lost by this fact. - TX - A sorry substitute for Arnold in the 1st film and Robert Patrick as the T-1000 in the 2nd.  She doesn't pull out any awe-inspiringly cool tricks like the T-1000 did, and her stone-cold-menace factor pales in comparison to the T-1000 as well as Arnold in the original.  Granted she had two pretty tough acts to follow, but if the film makers insisted on telling basically the same story for the 3rd time, they had to make up in style and cool effects what they sacrificed in lack of originality and predictability.Which brings us to STORY: I liked the 1st 2 terminator films, I didn't need to see them AGAIN during the 1st hour of this film.  The first hour had no tension or suspense because I'd seen it all before, and we knew none of the main characters would be killed by the TX anyway.  Had there been any spark of originality here it may have sustained my interest more than it did.  During the last half hour, the story finally goes somewhere new, but by that time even these late developments are utterly predictable.DIRECTING: Serviceable job by Jonathan Mostow, the action scenes are well structured, and the character scenes are watchable enough.  However the framing of the images doesn't compare with the stylistic touch James Cameron displayed in T2.WRITING: The dialog was succinct and to the point. No groan inducing lines, but nothing I'd call witty either.ACTION: A lot of people have apparently been wowed by the chase scene involving a crane driven at high speed while ripping up half the city. I'll say this for this scene, it's loud, and it certainly must've been expensive.  Again, there is absolutely no tension in this scene, and visually it is not as impressive as say the highway chase in Matrix Reloaded. I've seen plenty of chase scenes in my time, and a great many of them were better than this one. A fight scene between the two terminators towards the end of the film fares much better, mostly because (gasp!) I didn't know how it was going to end, and because the film makers wisely avoided the use of CGI stuntmen for the most part. You could really feel the weight of the metal crashing against the environment in this scene.EFFECTS: Like I said before, this film has basically nothing original story, character, or action-wise, putting a great burden on the effects to offer something to keep us interested. The result is ho-hum, although I must commend the restrained use of CGI during action scenes (a practice that has cost many other movies the suspension of disbelief from their audiences).So to summarize, T3 is a mildly fun action flick.  If that's all your looking for, by all means T3 will do the job.  Just don't be suckered by the under-hyping into thinking this a great film that's come to rescue the summer. As a fan of the series I liked where the story ended up, but the journey there was at times an exercise in mind numbing predictability.My Rating 6/10

Review title: The tradition of great SFX continues
Review_body: The latest installment of the Terminator movies will not only thrill fans, but also impress the casual viewer. Time isn't wasted on useless sentimentality as this movie kicks into action from the very beginning. Schwarzenegger reprises his role to perfection and thankfully keeps the cheesy one-liners to a minimum.Although it is noticeably missing the James Cameron touch, director Jonathan Mostow certainly delivers a quality picture worthy of becoming part of the trilogy. Some bad acting and poor writing hinder this from being a perfect film, but that was almost to be expected. Still, experience T3 on the big screen along with great sound, and you won't be disappointed.

WOW! WOW! I went into this movie expecting just another rehash of T2! BOY WAS I WRONG! Everything about this movie is great! The acting was great, although Kristanna Loken was a bit of a downer, she could've been better. The story took the T franchise into a whole new direction. Lemme also say that as an Arnold fan AND a HUGE T fan, I was never skeptical of this movie. It's not as PG-13 friendly as most of you people think either, at one point the TX shoves her arm through a guy's back and out the other side, I won't say who though since I'm not one for spoilers. Overall a worthy addition to the T franchise, it's GREAT!

Review title: A Solid Entry in The Series
Review_body: I saw "Terminator 3" tonight at a sneak preview.  I thought that it was a solid entry in the series.  I do believe that "T2" is the best installment in the series then i would say T3 then the first Terminator.  Alot of people will disagree with me on how I rate the movies in that order.  Terminator 3 did not have as much drama as the first two but it still had its fair share. The action sequences were great and the story was well told. Arnold gives a great performance as the terminator.  The T-X was on the same level as the T-1000 as the villan.  T3 was a solid entry the series and a must see for Terminator fans and action fans.  Also i say it was better than the Matrix Reloaded.

This movie is by far the best film released since the "Summer" began. It doesn't get as heady as The Matrix Reloaded, and its action has a more purposeful feel, rather than the destruction-for-destruction's sake of The Hulk.The actors suit their roles perfectly. Arnold hasn't aged a bit since T2, and the T-X is a refreshing change from the T-1000. John Conner is well played by Nick Stahl and Claire Danes as Kate Brewster does a very decent job in her part.My only complaint in the James Cameron v. Johnathan Mostow debate being that Mostow seemed to opt for a few too many slow-mo shots for dramatic effect. Other than that minor issue, I really think Mostow did a fine job of following Cameron's T2. There is a good amount of "tasteful" humor, too.As for the story, the formula is much the same as T2 -- for the most part. Our Terminator is dispatched to stop the T-X who was programmed to kill John Conner and his commanders. There are enough plot twists to keep you interested without delving into melodrama. The whole plot is just believable enough (all things considered) to entertain.My main complaint is that the musical score for T3 uses nothing of Brad Fiedel's awesome score for the previous films. There is a redux of the "Terminator" theme nearer to the end, but I feel the lack of Fiedel's cold, mechanical themes detracted from an otherwise perfect action film. The movie has many great throwbacks and references to the prior films so the omission of such great themes was a pretty big disappointment for me. Overall a great action film, and the best yet for this Summer.

This movie was absolutely awesome from start to finish.  Words alone cannot describe how I feel about this movie.  I highly recommend this movie to any movie-goer.  And, as a final note Bye-Bye Matrix Reloaded you've been terminated.

Review title: With a slight bit of cheese, T3 still works for me
Review_body: I was kind of reluctant in seeing this movie today but I am very glad I did. T3 really lives up to the other two. The weaponry of the terminatrix kind of left me uneasy and I was asking "How could the car speed up when she killed the guy by impaling him and she was in the back seat?" Oh well, all in all it was still a good movie. A couple of things I liked about the movie was an AWESOME chase scene with the crane. The best I have seen in a long time. Also the ending (I wont give it away) was reminiscent of my feelings of when I watched the end of the `The Planet of the Apes.' Should you go see it in the theaters? YES. for the crane chase scene alone. yes yes yes. But for the rest of the movie?  Sure, why not. Although if your like me and you like everything to fit. some of the scenes might irk ya.

Review title: The original is horrible, but watch the "Coming Storm" Cut
Review_body:
The movie in the theatrical cut is just a bad parody of terminator 2. Its not a serious movie by any means.
But the Coming Storm cut removes all bull and turns it into a quite watchable movie. Dont (re-)watch anything else!

When I heard they were making another terminator movie, I didn't know what to expect. After seeing this movie though, I was really impressed. I honestly believe this movie is very good. Yes some of the jokes were really lame, like the talk to the hand thing, but many other complaints people have with the movie are unjustified. People have been complaining that Nick Stahl acted "lost" in the movie. Yet that was an element of his character. Even Arnold who's now around 60 was great. Claire Danes who doesn't do many action movies was wonderful in the movie. Not to mention Loken, who is amazing, acted her part pretty well. I'm not arguing that this movie is the best terminator. Yes we all know that Cameron is a great director, but Mostow is one too. The action and story are amazing. People have been complaining about how the movie doesn't require enough thought, but seriously the third time around I think everyone understands the concept by now. There wasn't much need to explain the war. Terminator 2 did that great. This movie is an excellent movie that I believe will make an excellent addition to the terminator series. My only concern is that in order to milk the franchise, future movies will begin to suck. Let's just hope I'm wrong. WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!

Well its no Terminator 2 Judgement day which still rates as the best of the trilogy, but its still a good film.  I think why I personally like it so much as it completes the movie cycle.  In the first film we when shown glimpses of a possible future and same in T2, but in the closing momments of T3, we see the cycle complete as the Skynet takes over and starts the nuclear holocaust.My favorite moment has to be the ending, in the 2nd film we had hope for the future, and up until the end of T3 we had the same hope.  All that changes the moment they realise that they are in a bunker.  I personally felt the angst as they knew that there was nothing they could do to stop Skynet.  I had tears in my eyes as the missiles launched and we saw humanity reduced to shreds, it was a powerful emotional ending.  Director Jonathan Mostow should be congratulated for a risky ending which works.In order that we can enjoy the first two movies, this ending which was a total shock has to happen.  The script I confess is a little weak and it does lack James Camerons magic touch, but i did enjoy the film and I really think its a good one to end the series.  I love the terminator movies but I think it should end here.I personally rate 3.5 out of 5, not the best but still a good movie.

Review title: Too Short, Poor Acting, Lacking Depth, Weak Film
Review_body: I thought that this film was a poor effort considering the amount of money spent. The TX was bland and she was no where near the level of the T1000 played by Robert Patrick. The ending was okay I suppose but was it done so that another T film can be made ? I think it was. This vehicle should have finished after the 2nd film and it is now going down the route of other classics such as Jaws, Rocky, Rambo where the original films were really good but Rocky 2 and T2 apart the subsequent sequels just got worse and worse. Not a good film, Arnie stick to politics , your movie career is finished!!

Review title: Missing the atmosphere T1 and DID have
Review_body: It completely lacks the cool and sinister atmosphere from the first 2 episodes.Furthermore, the part where the little lady cries "Die you bitch" when the terminator was glued to the particle accelerator caused a lot of hilarity in the theater. The main characters are hardly convincing.The only person starring is miss Loken, being the only person to keep her mouth shut. (Apart from "I like your car/gun").Shame, this is just another action movie.

didn't expect much since cameron didn't direct, but whoa...they really went all out, one action sequence after another, tightly integrated at a super fast rate.best summer action movie of the 2003 hands down, with matrix reloaded at a close second. :)

I was a huge T2 fan, so I've been waiting for this movie for a long time. I'm glad to say that I was not disappointed at all.The movie was exciting, funny, clever, and delivered exactly what I wanted.
There were a couple cheesy scenes, but for the most part, the movie was great.  The Terminatrix was actually cool, even though I initially thought casting a woman was a mistake.I had a great time, and will definitely see it again and buy the DVD.

Review title: Great action, tried too hard to come up with a funny line.
Review_body: Lots of action, always like new characters, especially hot ones. One of the few amusing scenes occurred in the beginning.There's a cliff hanger of an ending, so i'm sure they'll be a T4 in a few years. If you liked the previous terminators, it's worth the price of a ticket.

Review title: In a summer where film companies are dishing out loads of pointless sequels to mediocre movies, it's a big surprise when one of these sequels actually comes out as something other than a complete copy of it'
Review_body: In a summer where film companies are dishing out loads of pointless sequels to mediocre movies, it's a big surprise when one of these sequels actually comes out as something other than a complete copy of it's predecessor. Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines succeeds where so many sequels fail: in originality. With the movie's star cast, fantastic action sequences and impressive story, it's not hard to guess that T3 will go down in film history as one of the most engaging action/sci-fi movies ever created.T3 focuses on John Connor (Nick Stahl), leader of the human resistance against the machines in a futuristic war-torn planet Earth. John, having stopped judgment day 12 years ago with the help of T-101 (Arnold Schwarzeneggar), has broken off all contact with the world and has become a drifter, knowing deep down that judgment day is still near. A new terminator, the T-X (Kristanna Loken) is sent into the present to kill John Connor and his future lieutenants. The story also involves Katherine Brewster (Claire Danes), a veterinarian's assistant who plays a key role in John Connor's life and the future of the resistance. Another T-101 is sent into the present to ensure the protection of John Connor and Katherine Brewster, and to lead them to safety before the coming of judgment day.The story to T3 is very strong, considering the fact that Terminator creator James Cameron is missing this time around. His replacement for this entry is Jonathan Mostow (U-571), who does a superb job in recreating James Cameron's vision of the future and of the machines who rule it. The story does a good job in answering questions such as why judgment day is still going to happen, and the roles that each character plays in the future. The story will make the viewer believe that there was a need to make this sequel, because there was still a story to tell.The actors in this movie stay true to their roles. Arnold is back, and although it's safe to say that this will probably be his last Terminator flick, he does a great job in reprising his role as the protector of John Connor. Edward Furlong, who played John in T2: Judgment Day, is missing this time around, but his replacement Nick Stahl keeps things going as the young man who still questions his role in life. Kristanna Loken is good as the Terminatrix. She brings the attitude and personality that Robert Patrick portrayed in T2. Claire Danes does a good job in her role, seeing that this is her first big role in an action movie.In conclusion, Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is a top-notch action movie that does just about everything right. T3 brings the classic movies together into one unforgettable sequel that will be sure to please fans of the original movies.

Review title: visual masterpiece, if you like that kinda stuff...
Review_body: the movie was conjested with action and special effects which took away from a strong plot line and good characters.  the visuals were excellent, although many things were regurgitated from the previous films.  many people will like this film for its stunning visual effects, and many people will hate it for its lack in good dialouge, plot, and characters.  i feel it would be worth while to see if you want to know what happens next in the terminator story, but dont expect the same feelings of intrigue or the same vibe from the characters like the cold, evil t-1000.  i think of t3 as a 'give the visual effects guys a bunch of money and see what they can do' kinda movie rather than a good sequel to a previously good movie.

I saw this movie and it rocks a million times more! I thought the first two were awesome, but this certainly topped it off for the Terminator flicks. It seems that every time they make another movie it gets better with Terminator, I recommend it!

Maybe I'm too big an Arnie fan, but wow, this one is great. As far as scifi goes, the Terminator series is near the top, from its classic beginning through its cgi marvel, to this great scifi action movie. It's machine filled mania, from the gigantic to the small, all killers.

I really liked Terminator 3. As a "Terminator" fan, though, it would have been better if James Cameron was still on the scene, and how about killing off Sarah Conner? Still though, a VERY good movie compared to some other movies I know, and the T-X character adds most of the action on this film, which makes it a great film! Highly recommend it. 9.4/10 stars.

Perhaps the best reason for true Terminator fans to see Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is unintended.  It compels you to pop the original Terminator, or Terminator 2: Judgment Day, into the DVD player/VCR when you come home from the theater, and realize all over again how unbelievably strong the first two films are, especially in comparison to this weak third installment.  Because, other than a noteworthy performance from Arnold Schwarzenegger, some good set design, and a few small touches that recall T1 & T2, the film cannot compensate for poor pacing, lack of a cohesive point-of-view, and a complete turnabout of the fundamental philosophy behind the whole series.  "The future is not set" captures the essence of the character's struggle against the machines--the belief that even the least among us could make a difference.  Whereas if T3 is to be believed, perhaps we should all simply accept our fate and go along with the plan--after all, it makes for better SFX.  The machines have apparently already won this war.

This movie gave me the impression that it was made mechanically (by Terminators??), with no real thought put into it; a rushed production. The timing/pacing was average, but was probably limited by a weak script to begin with. Despite plenty of action scenes, I nearly found this movie to be. . . boring".  Although there were some novel action scenes, they were nothing really spectacular, and the people scenes lacked interest due to the weak plot. I was struggling to retain interest by the end. Kristanna was miscast for the role of T-X, as her performance was not convincing as a Terminator. The remaining principle character performances (including Arnold) were not entirely convincing at times either. Again, this was probably due to the weak script. Technically competent. Artistically, this movie was limited. Overall rating of 6/10.

Where should i start, this movie was great. I came in wanting Alot of action and Violence, and got that. And i love the not so happy ending, they pulled it off rather nicely. All in ALl, as a big fan of Arnold and Terminator, i gotta give a 10 on this one.

Although, I was skeptical before going to see this film, the movie proved I was worrying needlessly. Everything that made the previous movies wonderful was right there yet again. Action, thrills, plot twists, some humor, and plenty of heart stopping moments. The characters were interesting and three dimensional, and one could not help becoming concerned about their fates. The movie was also intelligent, requiring the viewer to stop and consider new concepts and ideas. There were a few continuity errors with the timeline, but all in all, Terminator 3 is one wild ride well worth watching.

You can forget the Fourth of July fireworks this year, the real action's in the theater.  Arnold Schwarzenegger opens up a big can of worms with the best chase scene ever and more explosions than CNN's coverage of the bombing of Baghdad.  Jonathan Mostow pulled off very well a movie that many thought was going to be just an expensive knock-off of Terminator 2: Judgement Day. It fits seamlessly into the Terminator timeline as the next logical step in the war on the machines.

This movie (for me) out did itself. I went to see it with the "This is the third movie in this series, is it going to be worth it" attitude, but came out feeling that my money was really well spent. The movie was great, and all action movie lovers will agree with me, once they've seen this film. The car chase in this movie was one of the best I've ever seen in any movie. I feel it's really worth seeing. All I can say is, I'm waiting for T4 to come out, and I hope it's as good as this one.

Review title: Not the best, Not the worst
Review_body: While this movie is good, it certainly is not as good as its 2 predecessors. Although the story is good, Kristanna Loken as the TX does not carry the film. Arnold continues to amaze with his physique (not bad for a 55+/- y.o.) but he has had better roles. His reprisal of the T101 terminator did not do him or the character any justice. I can see where the story line would allow for part 4 but I would hope that the powers that be would let it end here.

Review title: They spent over $170 million on this?
Review_body: I went into this movie not expecting much, afterall it lacked Linda Hamilton, James Cameron, even the man that did the musical score. Arnold was there but, hey, you've seen the type of movies he has been in lately. Lets just say you can tell this wasn't written by Cameron. Its doesn't even seem to be written to any coherent line of reason. Why would the Terminatrix go after John's lieutenants if the other two could care less in the past? Why did her hand magically fix itself when her programming told her it was broken? Why would Sarah Connor fill her coffin with weapons? How does a machine remote control cars when no such computer exists in said cars? How the hell did the Terminatrix even find and then outrun John's truck with that huge semi truck (They can't move THAT fast!) Where did the computer virus come from? How is Skynet still Skynet since it was originally a mainframe but now a software program? The original films say Skynet killed virtually everyone when they tried to pull the plug when humanity feared Skynet's sentience yet here they supposedly can't since its "software" and not "hardware". So the memory of the Terminator from T2 was false since that data came from Skynet? Why didn't this Terminator kill humans since he didn't swear to John like T2 and especially since he could only take orders from Claire Danes? What was up with the one liners by Arnold? How was this Terminator's power source different from the two prior movies? In Terminator and T2 you see the main power source is in the abdominal area with a back up. Here he has some stupid slot where he can crack it open and turn it into a mini nuclear bomb. Why did the military have multiple prototypes? Last time I checked a prototype of anything was simply that one piece to be tested and then built in mass if it worked. Why the hell did the place even have a particle accelerator when their work in the lab had nothing to do with atomics?!?!? How did the Terminatrix even pull herself off the magnet when it was never turned off? Why did John continue to hang around the L.A. area if he didn't want to be found? And this is only a few of my problems with the flick. The acting wasn't that good (John is definately not an inspiring leader), the plotting was slow, and they attempted too much humor (the growing breasts was useless and sophmoric). James should have gone with the original T2 ending of John Connor playing in the future with his daughter as Sarah watched talking of how they averted Judgement Day. This trash was far from worthy of the Terminator name and, funniest of all, I saw this movie the day after the premier and the theater was virtually empty. Is that a good sign?

Though T3 is very competent, it lacks the heart of its 2 predecessors. The film plays like a series of elaborate action scenes (all done very well), with an occasional plot twist thrown in for good measure. Arnold is Arnold, though his quips seemed forced and a bit stale. As for the rest of the cast, they give a workman like effort, yet I felt the film was a bit flat.  I don't necessarily think T3 missed James Cameron, as director Jonathan Mostow has a good eye and films his action sequences with a real amount of flair and some nice bravado.  However, it seemed more of an exercise in excess than actually adding to the terminator franchise. Ultimately the film gives good bang for the buck, but I left feeling cold and uncaring much like the title's namesake.

Review title: A let down beyond all beliefs
Review_body: I have been a fan of the series my entire life, having seen the first two movies dozens of times (saw the first terminator at the age of 7 initially). After seeing this third installment yesterday, my heart was completely broken.  I didn't think I would take it that seriously, since it is just a movie, but I guess I did.  This is my favorite series after all, and I've been looking forward to the sequel for the last ten years.      What I saw, however, was not a terminator movie, but something else.  With all due respect to Mr. Mostow, it felt as if he had a vendetta to remove every single element that James Cameron had used to make the first two movies what they were, and expect this to be even half a decent sequel.  What was he thinking?  This movie turned into a disaster on a grand scale.  The terminator was completely ruined.  In the first movie, the terminator was portrayed as a cyborg from the future with no sympathy for its victims, and a mission to accomplish.  It was a killing machine, and in my opinion, it looked frightening, and serious.  The second movie I thought did an equally acceptable job at painting this picture.  Both movies had the right music, the right mood, and the suspense required for us to believe that these terminators are not playing around, not to mention the sympathy for the main characters.  They had a very dark touch to them, and seeing the movies as a little kid gave me the creeps.  In this sequel they took that entire aspect, and ripped it out, leaving it as a souless parody.  First off, where did that music go?  That was essential to the movies, but apparently it was decided to be unnecessary this time around.  Second, is this supposed to be the terminator, or a kindergarten cop?  What is the deal with all the poorly written jokes and the ridiculous one liners.  "Talk to the hand", "I'm back" - give me a break, this is supposed to be the terminator, but they decided to turn it into one long gay joke.  The T-X did not participate nearly enough in the story, and definitely did not display it's full potential. Frankly, I was not impressed.  Instead of an evil terminator, the T-X acted more like that evil alien dressed like a Victoria Secret model from Men in Black 2, although I can't say that I wasn't impressed by the entrance. Bottom line is that the 170 million dollar budget went into some special effects and nothing else.  Here you hardly even get to see the terminators killing their victims, most of it is off screen.  Where is the blood? What's the point of the R rating?  The budget for Terminator 1 was under $7 million, and a lot more was done with that, a LOT more.  Maybe I came in with too high expectations, and the next time I watch the film it won't seem as disappointing.  But  so far all I saw was a Sci-Fi channel original presentation.

Review title: Only average if you haven't seen the first two movies!!!
Review_body: I just got done watching T3 and at best it was brutal, I love the first two movies and this doesn't even compare, CAMERON WHERE ARE YOU!!!!,  I just want to know how did they get away with destroying the franchise like this, All true fans of the series will see this movie as nothing else but a few descent action scenes and waste of 170 million dollars. It's a sad day if your a fan of the series they just KILLED IT !!My Rating 5/10 , just because I'm such a fan of the first two!!!

Review title: Back to back home runs with T2 and T3
Review_body: Terminator was a great movie in it's own right. It was an 80s horror film that introduced many of us to Arnold (those of us who hadn't seen Conan). However, Terminator lacked intricacy in it's writing and plot. That problem was quickly resolved in Terminator 2, which showed us that there was so much more to the future, Skynet, and Cyberdyne systems than we thought. Terminator 2 not only brought more story to the table, but more action. It also introduced us to a couple of great actors (Robert Patrick, Edward Furlong). The long anticipated Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines picked up right where T2 left off. Where can you go from T2, some may ask? The story was already brought to a conclusion, right? Wrong. Just when you thought you knew everything, you finally realize that you hardly anything. T3 does exactly what T2 did for Terminator. It takes us even DEEPER into the world of the Terminators and answers a lot of questions that many of us had after T2. The creators of this movie took a series that seemingly had it's strings tied up and created a whole new chapter that is brilliant in it's depth. Not only does T3 bring a great story to the table just as T2 did, but it too brings blockbuster action. After watching T3, it's arguably the best action movie of this summer. Mostow does a great job of filling in for Cameron (we miss you James!). It's truly enjoyable to watch action movies as they used to be made...without much aid of computers. Matrix Reloaded was great...but it relied heavily on computer imagery. Most of T3's action is genuine, jaw dropping stunts. And just as T2 introduced us to new Hollywood faces, so too does T3. Nick Stahl, who plays John Connor, has a great deal of acting talent. He brings his own touch to the character of Connor, now 20 something. We see a whole new side of Connor, very different from the one we saw in T2. In T2, Connor was a rebellious teen who just wanted to have a good time with his friends at the arcade. T3 shows us a worn down, depressed, junkie. Stahl did an excellent job of pulling off the role. He reminded me very much of Tobey Macguire in this movie, perhaps due to his narration and soft-spoken demeanor. We're also introduced to Kristanna Loken, who plays the T-X. It's hard to gauge whether anyone who's recruited to play a terminator truly has any acting talent. The role just doesn't do actors any justice. They must literally constrain their acting talents to the confines of a robot. We obviously know, now, that Schwartzenegger and Patrick were better actors than their terminator roles made them out to be. So too will be the case, I believe, with Loken. Not just anyone can play the role of a terminator. It takes a certain breed and I believe the creators of T3 did a great job of casting. All in all, I give this movie a 9.5, but seeing as that's not a choice, I just rounded up to 10. Bash me if you wish, but I suggest you see the movie. It really is worth the time and money. It delivers in every possible way.

Review title: pointless re-do of T2 without feeling....
Review_body: T3 is nearly a clone of T2 but without the interesting concepts and humor that made Judgment Day a classic sci-fi actioner.Although there are a few interesting visuals and a plot that could have been worthwhile if it had been fleshed out a lot more and infused with a little more originality,Rise of the Machines is ultimately a vehicle for Arnold to utter humorless one-liners and do constant non-stop action sequences with a villain that is nearly a carbon copy of Robert Patrick in T2.Curiously,this film does have an intriguing finale but it is not enough to save the overall movie.Too much action,not enough brains.It's time to let go of the Terminator franchise.No T4 please...

This movie has the best damn car chase I've seen in a long time.  It blew the Matrix away in terms of action-packed explosioney car crashes and combat.  I just can't wait for the fourth now, with the way this one ended.

Review title: 3rd installement is taking series in right direction but too slow.
Review_body: Terminator 3 is really based on scripts that have been flying on net since 1999. Some of the scripts that this movie is mainly based are called T3:Armageddon and its many versions over the years.(Personally the older versions were great) Those scripts call for Arnold Terminator back right before skynet takes over and with Linda and young John he helps them to survive through nuclear holocaust and then fights along Johns side. Now the T3 movie itself is very close to this script. John is saved and Arnold terminator ensures John survives the holocaust but of course his mother is already dead for while. Anyways, the movie itself is on fast pace with battles between T-X and Arnold as John and his future wife(Claire) basically are running away. The action sequences are good. The best part of the movie is when skynet is turned on and together with interacion of the global virus it takes over. Early prototype machines take over in the military building that John gets to trying to prevent judgement day. That's when Arnold gets to fight his precedessors for once and not the advanced TX. Kick ass. However, I wish we would see more of the Skynet taking over. Further the scripts that have been flying on the net explained why Skynet computer system actually turns against humanity. In this movie its not explained, although if you read the scripts you would understand possibly what the virus really was:)(hacker who admires world power and have Hitler for his idol). But, back to the actual movie. It seems that instead of showing us the judgement day and post battle to save humanity Jonathan Mostow decides to widely extend the TX vs T101 battles and finishes the movie on guess what(judgement day) so it's a perfect setup for T4(post nuclear warfare between men and machine). This should and could have been succesfully done in one movie, T3, but at least T3 takes the right direction. I was afraid this movie is gonna bring another ending where they think they prevented judgement day, thank god they didn't.

I've seen mixed reviews everywhere, and understandably so.  This is perhaps one of the most hyped-films of the year (right next to Hulk and Return of the King), and quite a few less-than-promising factors involved (no James Cameron, no Sarah Connor).But let's get to the point:  Was it a great action flick?  Absolutely. Does it make significant headway into the SkyNet storyline?  Definitely?  Did the audience cheer?  Oh yes.Nit-picky details aside, this movie continued to build, build, build (in a wonderful array of action sequences than truly put you in the seat of danger, and in developing the new characters).  It climaxes with the inevitable activation of SkyNet, and leaves you wanting more in the end.Great movie.  Perhaps I am not a professional reviewer, but I am anxiously anticipating T4.

I am a huge fan of the Terminator films and since i saw the first trailer I've been hoping this film doesnt suck and ruin the franchise (a la Batman and Robin).  Well they pulled it off.  While its not as good as T2, T3 is certainly an action packed film from the start, and I thought it was awesome.  It moves along at a much faster pace than the previous two films, therefore it lags behind the others in plot and story, however its right up there with them in adreniline pumping action and that occasional humor. However, the timline explained in this film is even more messed up than the timeline in T2 believe it or not.  Am I the only person who has ever noticed that in T2 when the T1000 looks up John in the police database it specifically says he is 10?  Well, those are the only gripes I have cause the rest of the film was awesome and I will see it again.

Review title: What a great movie - Arnold is back.
Review_body: This is a great movie.  Great action, good story...an enjoyable hour and a half with some popcorn and coke.  If you go looking for the meaning of life from this movie will be disappointed.  If you're looking for a great action movie with Arnie in it...go see T3 - it delivers!!

Terminator 3 was average at best. This film had no sense of pacing in my opinion and spent no time at all letting us get to know the characters. Cameron's absence was very obvious. Instead of taking time to build up to each climax terminator 3 just threw it all at us in the beginning and then went down hill from there, throwing chase seen after chase seen and battle after battle until the very predictable ending. The TX that was supposed to be all powerful got her ass kicked all the time and didn't fare half as well as the T-1000 did in T2. I felt like i had hardly seen Arnold in the movie and they spent practically no time on the TX at all other than a few stupid scenes where she said "hey..i like ur bike" and "hey i like ur car". At the end of terminator 2 i felt like i knew the all the character better, terminators and all. This movie didn't allow us to get to know anyone and i felt like the director didn't really care about that aspect of movie making. This movie is a disgrace to the terminator series and has ruined the greatness the series had. If i had never seen the other terminator movies i may have given this movie a 6, but since i have and i love the other two this movie gets a big 4 and a warning to all who love the terminator series and have yet to see this movie.Only watch this movie if u don't care about the other movies or ur really into special effects and explosions and you just want a action movie where no brain activity is required. I only can pray they don't make terminator 4. God help us if they do.

Too much action and so litle of whats going on. If you take all the action scenes you'll get a 10 minutes movie. I think it doesn´t stands for the Terminator's movie quality standard and I just give it a 5.
Of course I'll be in the theaters for terminator 4 (just hope it can get a 10).

Review title: Definitely the Best Terminator Movie of them All
Review_body: I saw the entire trilogy back to back to back. This one was definitely the best. In the first, the music was like something out of a video game and it was more of a ridiculous love story than a science fiction action film. The second film was a little better than the first because it focused more on the time travel aspects and the war in the future. I liked the fact that John Connor was a bit of a motorcycle punk. That's the kind of guy I'd elect to be a military leader, but I didn't like the idea that Sarah Connors was in the insane asylum. In "Rise of the Machines", however, it made a terrific link to the war in the future. The terminator (Model # T-X), who was both more powerful and hotter than the other two, had multiple targets and most of them were killed. Therefore, its mission was mostly a success. The only down side to this movie is that the creators brought back THE Terminator, Arnold Scharzenegger. I don't think that Arnold really should be in any more of the Terminatory movies. Finally, after watching this movie, I felt that it could be a good ending, but it could also be added on to. For example, the fourth terminator movie, if there ever will be one, could deal with John not having all the generals he would have had for the war and how humankind can overcome its follies with machines.I give this movie a 10 out of 10. For Terminator fans and general Sci-Fi fans, i would highly recommend this movie. Unfortunately, I wouldn't recommend it to little kids, tho. Hence, the R rating.

Don't get me wrong I am a Terminator fan but you got to know when things aren't so good, and this movie wasn't all it was hyped up to be. It had action scenes and what not but no real base line to it story wise. You already know what Terminator is about but there could have been more added to the story line, they explain things well so it wasn't very hard to catch on at all, but it seems like there is something missing not enough effort on this one. The end just leaves you wanting more but not on a good basis. You can obviously tell there will be a forth movie I just hope it will be better than this one hopefully a little more complex not just cheesy wannabe catch phrases and a pair of sun glasses.

This is a bad bad movie, how can anyone say its the best film this year, or one of the best movies ever, or even better than T1 or T2???I'm sorry but I had to commentSome of the acting had me cringing, from Danes, Terminatrix and even Arnie, some of it really sticks in my mindAnd what was with the deliberate bad one liners from Arnie? jeezus, think of some new ones! They had me cringing, noticably (putting my hands over my head in disgrace), not to mention Arnie comming out of the stipping club with his "new shades" (youve been warned) it pained me to see what this film was doing to the other 2Obviously some people will be total suckers for it and think it's funny, but at the end of the day they have turned it into a cheesy kids version of T2, its disgusting. Right lets get this straight, T1, and T2 were serious films, thats what made them so great, T1 was a daaark film, its a masterpiece, T2 was just as good but managed to do it being a blockbuster aswell (and was also dark and serious), T3 aboloshes all of this with appaling acting, lame story, terrible one liners trying to be deliberatly funny, since when were they meant to be deliberatly funny??? Is Arnie trying to win the audience over? "Please like me again, pretty please" Argh its painfullAnd since when was Arnie worth $30 million for this? That has to be the easiest money in history, he did hardly anything in here to desrve it, it wasnt even acting he just muttered some lines in a terminator voice,
Also, I did give a monkeys about Arnie and John Conner in T2, but why didnt I give a damn about em in this film? Bad acting, bad script? i dunnoIt certainly lacked a biiiiig something, James Cameron, thats whatOn the plus side, there was some good action, if thats what u want, but all in all I was very dissapointed, and I will laugh at people who say they like this cos they obviously dont know what a good film is, they obviously wont know what good acting is, or a good script,I am now mentally scarred.5/10

Review title: If you love the license.....don't see it.
Review_body: I'm both a big Terminator fan and both a James Cameron fan, and him not directing really shows in this movie. The action was average at best (and for some of you that have written that the crane scene in Terminator 3 was better than the highway scene from The Matrix : Reloaded.......right) The story, while it did fit into the trilogy, wasn't really elaborated on. The comedy was funny, but very out of place for this kind of movie. And Arnold didn't have many lines besides his catch phrases. It looks like this movie was thrown together in one sitting, with the sole purpose of just making money off the public, and not to get a quality movie out for the people that have been waiting over a decade for it.

Review title: Once again, we learn to ignore the critics...
Review_body: I must admit, I was a bit concerned when I strolled into the theatre to see the latest edition to the terminator saga. But only for a minute.  The special effects are some of the best yet, and if I'm not mistaken, didn't the previous two set the bar for their time as well? This was an all around fun movie, with as much destruction and stoic one liners as can be crammed into a two hour movie. Whoever missed James Cameron in this film was also to busy reminiscing to perceive how good this movie really is.Granted, T-X was no-where near as sinister as the T-1000, but you were kept wondering up until the last 5 minutes of the movie how they were going to get rid of her. Now, the ending is exactly what I would hope for. A complete twist, slightly predictable, but exactly as I would like it to be. I will say no more for those who haven't seen it yet. I predict that the nay-sayers will keep a few from seeing this movie at first, but once it gets out how great this movie is, it may be one of the biggest action movies ever.

I went in to Terminator 3 unsure of what I was going to get and came out empressed. Why was I empressed:T3 - James Cameron, Linda Hamilton, Edward Furlong = Potential DisasterWith the odds going against him Jonathan Mostow pulled it off, he made T3 without any of the above elements and the end product was really good. Nick Stahl does a great job of taking Edward Furlong's place as John Conner, putting lots of emotion and grit into the part. Claire Danes does a magnificent job as Kate Brewster, also adding some raw emotion to her part. At age 56 Arnold looks as tough as ever as the Terminator proofing age is nothing but a number. Kristanna Loken does well as the T-X, a robot b!tch who just doesnt seem to go away. The storyline was well written and the action sequences were awesome. If you have not seen T3, go see it! But DO NOT compare it to the first two, because T3 was not James Cameron's work. My rating: 8 out of a possible 10

T3 was a delight!!!! It was action packed and everything in the storyline was explained very well. Arnold looked to be in tremendous shape. Many people complain about the TX being a girl, but you really don't even worry about while watching T3. There are bigger issues than her. So, to answer everyone's question: Did it live up to the hype? YES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It was an amazing piece of cinema. I recommend seeing it more than once in the theatres.

After being completely disappointed by the horrendous extended A-Team episode known as T2, (Maybe the biggest drop of in quality from original to sequel ever) I was prepared to really hate T3. Maybe the lower expectations played a role, but the movie surprised me. It doesn't live up to the original of course, but it far surpasses T2. The action is tremendous, the fight scenes between the Terminators are much better than in T2, and the chase scene outdoes The Matrix Reloaded in my opinion. Throw in a great ending and I'm actually hoping we won't have to wait ten years for the next one.

After watching a lot of recent overhyped films I'd expected Terminator 3 to be boring and predictable. I was pleasantly surprised by the interesting storyline that many sequels lack. The action in the movie was extremely good and the acting was also above my expectations.

As a huge Terminator fan, I rushed to see the sneak preview of T3 on Tuesday, July 1.  This movie was a mess.  Nick Stahl, while a talented actor, was just not cut out for this role.  Also, there was way too much product placement.  The magic of the first two is gone forever.  The Terminator series has turned into predictable Hollywood crap.  While I wasn't crazy about the softening up and kid-friendliness of Arnold in T2, the intensity and energy of that film was undeniable and kept you at the edge of your seat.  This element was absent in T3.  Stahl and Clair Danes just didn't contribute enough of an emotional element to carry the story. T1 was a landmark in action/sci fi films.  T3 is just typical Hollywood. I have to hand it to James Cameron.  He jumped off this sinking ship just in time.  (no Titanic jokes please!)P.S When did they start making Cyborgs with facelifts and nose jobs?

I just saw T3 at a screening. Very enjoyable, likely the best of the lot. Strong performances from Claire Danes and Nick Stahl helped humanize the over-the-top scenario. The only problem with the series' development is that the cyborgs keep becoming more omnipotent so that it strains credulity that they couldn't easily destroy a couple of mere out-of-shape mortals who can do little more than run or drive away. Still great stunt work, especially in the first part of the film. In fact, the first half uses up most of the adrenaline of the movie, which deflates the climax a bit. Should win awards for sound effects editing: tremendous! See it at a theatre with good sound system.

...but not worthy as a successor to T2.Great action sequences, big explosions, great chases, and even a little self depricating humor.  i liked that.  there was only one scene that i felt was overly contrived.  overall, it held my attention and kept the adrenaline pumping from start to finish.  Arnold looked great.but the plot was average and somehow just wasn't as intelligent as T2.  i know I'm not supposed to expect intelligence from an action flick, but i did.  The acting was wooden and characters were one sided.  I had trouble understanding everyone's motivation.  (except for the terminator himself who by definition is one sided, wooden, and motivated).  There were also some unexplained idiosyncracies that seemed like the director was going to do something more but then changed his mind.  but then at the other extreme, there were some things that were very obvious, but yet were still drilled into us again and again.overall, a good action flick.  but I was expecting more.

Anyone expecting T3: Rise of the Machines to be the next landmark film in the science fiction genre will be dissapointed.  But anyone looking for a quality action movie will not.  That's basically what this movie is: a quality movie that doesn't let it's viewers down.  We all know that T2 is one of the best action movies of all time and that pedigree makes this movie tough to live up to expectations.  But T3 comes through in some ways and doesn't in others.  The action is first rate ( I liked the fact there is very little cgi and a lot more real things being blown up), the actors turn in good performances (Arnold pretty much looks as he did in T2), and it makes you want to see T4 (if they make it).  The only problems i have with the film are very nitpicky.  There is somewhat of a lack of cinematography (it made me miss James Cameron's blue tinted T2), and the Terminatrix is so unbelievably beautiful that it was tough for me to be scared of her.  All in all, a pretty satisfying movie with good action, good performances, and some unexpected laughs thrown in.  **1/2 stars out of 4
i can just tell you right now that T3 is the best movie ever.it puts Matrix reloaded look very bad I cant wait for T4 T5 T6 the action is the best thing THATS A VERY GOOD DEAL

Review title: Trailer doesn't do the Movie Justice
Review_body: My expectations for this film were extremely low.  I thought this movie would give Arnold's career a KO, but it didn't happen!  When I saw a couple of the trailers for the film, I thought it was going to be a joke.  C'mon Arnold playing a "Terminator" at 55 and coming a from heart surgery a few years ago?  I mean Arnold is still in great shape but he couldn't possibly pull it off, right?  Wrong!  Physically, Arnold showed that he could still pull off the action genre.  The only area where he looked aged was in his face (slightly receding hairline and receding eyebrows, along with a few wrinkles.)  For a 55 year old man, I would pray to look like him.As for the movie, I truly believe it was the second best film in the trilogy.  Let's be real, T2 was probably the greatest action film of all time.  T3 came very close to surpassing the previous movie.  Along with a solid story, great stunts and special effects, I felt that the movie was money well spent!  After the bitterness of watching the Matrix: Reloaded, it felt good to see a an action movie with a decent plot.  Granted there are moments in the movie where some scenes and characters are hard to believe, but hey it's the movies!My suggestion, go have great time watching a TRUE summer flick!

***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** This movie was a great movie for me (a die hard terminator fan) with an AMAZING ending... I'm not gonna say anything to spoil it ;) It had a lot of comedy scenes though that kinda make fun of T2 but it was good nontheless... I guess they didn't wanna make it 2 serious because it would be dissapointing to people since nothing can be as good as T2 hahaha but yea... it sets up for what's to come later... nothing else will be said =) go watch the movie and read this and then you will get what I mean. Hope I didn't say 2 much : THIS IS A SPOILER DO NOT READ PAST THIS!!
 Why does the terminator (arnold) kill John? I didn't get the reason.

The first Terminator was great, the second was even better, and of course, twelve years later, I had my reservations about this installment of the series. My reservations are now laid to rest.Terminator is an amazing movie from start to finish, blending seamlessly traditional action, stunts, and fine elements of CGI which many times, you don't even notice is there. It successfully advances the plot to new areas, and raises interesting questions, while holding true to the many one liners the series is known for. Add to this a hot new terminator who can make her chest grow at will and get it on with the old T-800 in a bathroom, and you've got a good time on your hands.Terminator 3 gets better as it progresses until it ends with a climactic ending which is both incredible, and shocking. The series can only get better from here, and I have no doubt that the next installment will bring a whole new light to where it's going from here. If I have only one question to raise about this movie, it's where the 175 million dollars went... besides Arnold's pocket that is.

All in all, I liked this follow-up to the other two Terminator films. I do admit that I would have liked to see the original John and the a return of Sarah Connor, but I have to say that this new cast has got something new and fresh to add to the series. I don't understand this mess about not understanding the plot or the plot  does not have the Jim Cameron surprise flare to it. What?!? How can people say this was not surprising?!? Obviously some of the negative critics were not big fans of the other two movies. The plot was just continuing the story with a nice little twist at the end ( I smell a T-4....hmmm...) When leaving the theater,I wasn't sure I liked it much but now, after thinking about all of the different elements brought to the film, I see that T-3 was quite good (It will never be as large as the other two but very very very close in my mind...). I would give it an 8 out of 10. It was exciting, intense, non-stop action. The dialogue gets a little confusing and Ah-nold still doesn't ennunciate his words but I thought the story was really great. Any fan of The Terminator films will like this one. I do recommend it but MAKE SURE YOU SEE THE OTHERS BEFORE YOU SEE THIS ONE! Oh yeah, for those that do not like all the action packed things, there is a lot of classic humor and a small love story that play into the film. The ending is also sad and tear jerking....umm...yeah :-/ ....go and enjoy the film!

but leaves too many plot holes unfilled.  No shortage of action or Arnold one-liners.  The story is plausible, and is an interesting twist (especially the end) to the saga.  But what the film basically accomplishes is to set the stage and pave the way for T4, the post-apocalyptic story most fans probably want to see, and perhaps wanted to see in T3.

Review title: THE ABSOLUTE BEST FILM OF 2003! IT'S GOT EVERYTHING, YOU'LL LOVE IT!
Review_body: THE MOVIE OF THE YEAR HAS ARRIVED!  This was an absolute excellent movie and perfect new addition for the Terminator series.  The style and editing is kept in line with the previous' films design yet is expanded upon through action that is not-stop and unlike anything you've ever seen.  Besides that, THE SCRIPT IS BRILLANT.  It clears up ALL the plot holes you may have been wondering about from previous films such as "How the heck can a whiny civilian kid end up being the future leader of the human military resistance?" and "Does a 'terminator' being sent back to the past change the future timeline everytime one is sent back?".  The new characters perfectly fit the series and add incredible character development and archs to their personality.  T3 is an absolutely vital addition to the series and features SOME OF THE BEST ACTION SEQUENCES EVER CAPTURED ON FILM.  It also has a major emotional pull and some great dramatic scenes as characters live, die, and go through major changes before your eyes.  The acting is top-notch. Expect Loken and Stahl to become major stars after this one.  There are many twists and turns along the way too - THIS IS JUST ONE ROLLERCOASTER RIDE THAT NEVER LETS UP!  GO SEE IT AS MANY TIMES AS YOU CAN - YOU'LL LOVE IT!

Absolutely awesome. Arnold was such a bad ass.  Non-stop destruction and likewise, entertainment.  The story too was better than I expected it to be. They really did a lot to enhance the previous stories, instead of regurgitating stuff we were already aware of.  Overall it made it feel like a entirely new story instead of just a sequel.I can only hope that there will be a fourth.

As a big fan of the first two films, I was prepared to be disappointed. But T3 delivered everything you want a movie (or at least this movie) to do. Excellent story, characters, action, effects... it was all there and all good. You will holler at the screen. Go see this movie and enjoy it.

Spoiler Terminator 3 is horrible.  The dialogue is awful.  The acting lacks motivation.  There are too many catch lines.  In the beginning, the visual metaphor with the deer and the motorcycle insulted my intelligence.  And of course Arnold's exploding chest battery, established in the beginning, is going to kill "Terminatrix" in the end. It's all Hollywood, and nothing else.  Its not Arnold's FAULT; just Jonathan Mostow's.  The directing leaves everything to be desired.   And can you believe it, the movie ends when the machines BEGIN their "rise."  Why? Cause their going to make terminator 4.  The marketing ploy is sadly obvious.  If there is a bronze lining, it would be 1 of the action scenes; mediocre.

Arnold defintely returns, not only to the Terminator series, but to good action movies, from a slump of a few years. When I first saw the trailers for this movie I thought it looked like it was going to bomb, and be terrible, especially without Cameron directing it, and Hamilton not returning as Sarah Connor.  Then I started hearing good things about it closer to its release, so decided to go see it on it's premiere night. I was amazed, Mostow had pulled it off, a very excellent Terminator movie the lived up to its name.  It didn't have as much as a "dark" feel to it as much as the first two, but it did have everything else.  The action, the explosions, and Arnie.  A couple of scenes did feel like they were remakes from T2, but other than that it was pretty original. The hand-to-hand fighting scenes between the good and bad terminators were off the hook. It was also nice to see some of the machines from the "future wars" to appear in modern day.  Some of them didn't look too different from some of the spy planes that the US military are using today, which was kind of creepy. The ending was defintely the icing on the cake, throwing me for a loop, I never expected it to end the way it did.  This movie is better than Matrix Reloaded, and quite possibly the best summer action movie of 2003.

Review title: Finally, for the Terminator series fan...
Review_body: I applaud the creators for taking the time to making sure a sequel is true to its predecessors.  Although the plot is amazingly similar to the previous two Terminator films, it introduces enough new storyline content to make it interesting, and also leave you hungry for whatever may come next.The action scenes were definitely in-line with what you would expect from a $170 million dollar budget, and the character development was right-on.Having waited all this time for the next installment of the Terminator series, I found the movie was a must see, and I was not disappointed.

Review title: Best sequel I've seen in a while
Review_body: Even if T3 seems to be just a modified remake of T2, that alone should make it worth watching. As a sequel, T3 will undoubtedly be attacked as not breaking any new ground like T1 (in a thematic way) or T2 (pioneering computer imaging), and for dragging out a franchise and career of an actor that some say should have long been put to rest. As a great fan of the other two Terminator movies, however, I have no problem with a 3rd installment that hasn't changed much. It still has thrilling action that even blows away summer block-buster rivals Hulk and Matrix Reloaded, and sustains the excitement through its open-ended conclusion. The dialogue, chock full of one-liners resembling classic Ah-nold flicks like Commando and Total Recall, is a bit corny in spots, but is generally enjoyable. Interestingly, this sequel returns to the gloom and doom theme choice of T1, and not the playful "boy and his robot" type of lightness of T2. All in all, this has been the best action movie and best sequel I have seen in a long, long time.

Review title: So, so, so terrible. It boggles my mind.
Review_body: $170 million is just enough to get Arnold Schwarzenegger and some pretty impressive special effects. It's too bad that only left them with a $5 dollar budget for getting a screenplay together. Terminator was excellent. Terminator II might have been even better, but they were great because the story was interesting and the characters were worth watching. I watched the entire movie saying to myself, "alright...it can't get any worse." But it did...it most certainly did. Sorry to write a bad review.

Review title: James Cameron: where art thou? The spirit you gave T1 & 2 has been Terminated!
Review_body: Plot Details: This opinion reveals minor details about the movie's plot. T-3 doesn't have the feeling, spirit or intensity of T-1 or T-2. I say this with a heavy heart. T-1 & 2 are among my favorite movies of all time. Arnie is the perfect Terminator, and I love many of his movies. This is the first time I've seen Nick Stahl, Kristanna Loken, or Claire Danes, and they all did a great job. But the magic of the previous films was not there. The movie seemed like it was made by following the script and storyboards like a studio musician playing the notes from his sheet. Done correctly, but certainly not a Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, Jim Morrison... and others like them who gave performances that explode with intense passion. John Conner (Nick Stahl) He's burned out, on the run, doesn't have a plan or any direction, and a total wimp. Not even his Terminator obeys him. T-X (Kristanna Loken) She's the new Terminator, and like her predecessor, the T-1000 played by Robert Patrick in T-2, she can change her appearance (but confusingly has the hard steel skeleton of the earlier model T-800, that Arnold plays) So sometimes she's liquid steel, and sometimes not, since she can change from female to male. Her face is beautiful and exotic, and she can look very cold, confident, and robotic; but not wicked evil and totally dedicated like Patrick's Terminator of T-2. Kate Brewster (Claire Danes) Nice close-ups, a beautiful face and good acting, she played her part well. Still, there was simply not the intensity of purpose that Linda Hamilton brought to the previous films. T-800 (Arnold) Erroneously calling himself a T-101, Arnie, is back! Arnie, of course is `The Terminator,' so it's hard to screw-up that role. But he can only do what the script allows. He plays his part, delivers his one-liners, but is a different Terminator than he played earlier. Same model, but as we all know, the second Terminator played by Arnold, was terminated. So there is no `feeling' between him and John Conner, or Kate Brewester like there was in the earlier films between John and his mother Sara Conner. In fact it seems Arnold doesn't care about them at all. Music Score: What score? Although Terminator has one of the finest theme and soundtrack music in the history of modern movies, they simply didn't use it. It's like a Star Wars movie without the classic theme song. A major mistake.Tension, mood, drama, feeling, intensity, story, plot. ooops, completely forgot about all of that. Just cram in as much action and destruction as a movie can hold within one hour and 45 minutes. Special Effects: At least most of them were real (I hope) as opposed to computer generated. I'm talking about the `Vehicle' chase scenes. In this episode, female Terminator TX remotely controls un-manned police and fire engines, while simultaneously and physically driving a large crane on wheels, laying massive destruction in her path. Many cars and telephone poles lost their lives in this chase scene. While very destructive, it just didn't compare to previous Terminator chase scenes, especially the one in the concrete storm ditch of T-2. Surprisingly, special effects were minimal and not very impressive. The steel Terminator endoskeleton was the same as the original, so nothing new there and personally, I thought the flying robots looked very amateur and out-dated. The screening I attended was the first public showing in one of Los Angeles', newest and largest theatres. It was of course filled, but the audience reaction was very subdued. A few chuckled at some of the one-liners and one couldn't help but laugh at Arnie's first pair of sunglasses. Another laugh came when the Female Terminator TX saw a billboard with a Buxom model with the words: What is Sexy?' and decided to redirect some of her liquid steel to her chest area and - Viola! Instant breast enlargement! The interesting thing is the very favorable and quite audible reaction was by the females in the audience as they squealed with joy and envy at such power. In conclusion, I think the movie suffered without the direction of James Cameron. The plot was filled with holes the size of large nuclear craters. The movie was dependant on fast action to carry it, but other than the chase scene near the beginning, it just didn't. The ending was very weak, but its intent was quite obvious - it was a lead-in to Terminator 4. As Arnold likes to say: "I'll be back!" The Bottom Line:   Disappointment. Even still, I recommend seeing it because the series, like Star Wars, is a legend. It would leave a void otherwise, and it's necessary to understand future Terminator movies.

Review title: Great Fx, but is that enough?
Review_body: This did not live up to my expectations for the Terminator series.Yes, there are REAL fx, and the crane scene is fantastic.  It's tough to beat the cgi of the matrix, but reality is a lot scarier than a stop action fight scene on a semi.And yes, the terminatrix is amazing.  Great acting and cgi, but the T-1000 in T2 just seemed to be a lot scarier.  She held her own, and tried to play the T-1000 style, but...
